revision.text:
{{close paraphrasing|article|date=January 2016}} [[File:Bms rice planting 141229-47913 rwg.JPG|thumb|right|300px|Rice cultivation in Banyumas, Central Java.]] '''[[Agriculture]]''' is one of the key sectors within the [[Economy of Indonesia|Indonesian economy]]. While the sector's contribution to its national [[gross domestic product]] has significantly declined in the last 50 years, it currently remains an income generator for the majority of Indonesian households. In 2013, the agricultural sector contributed 14.43% to national GDP, a slight decline from 2003's contribution which was 15.19%.<ref>{{cite news|title=Satu Dekade, Kontribusi Pertanian terhadap PDB Menurun | author=Estu Suryowati| date=12 August 2014| newspaper=Kompas|url=http://bisniskeuangan.kompas.com/read/2014/08/12/105145826/Satu.Dekade.Kontribusi.Pertanian.terhadap.PDB.Menurun|language=Indonesian}}</ref> In 2012, the agricultural sector provides jobs to approximately 49 million Indonesians, representing 41% of the country's total labor force.<ref name="IndoInvest">{{cite web|title=Pertanian di Indonesia (Agriculture in Indonesia)|work=Indonesia Investments|url=http://www.indonesia-investments.com/id/budaya/ekonomi/ikhtisar-struktur-ekonomi/pertanian/item378|accessdate=5 December 2015}}</ref>
Currently, approximately 30% of Indonesia's land area is used for agriculture. Indonesian agriculture sector is supervised and regulated by the [[Ministry of Agriculture (Indonesia)|Indonesian Ministry of Agriculture]].<ref name="Kementan-Sejarah">{{cite web|title= Sejarah Kementerian Pertanian |work=Kementerian Pertanian RI (Indonesian Ministry of Agriculture) |url=http://www.pertanian.go.id/ap_pages/detil/7/2014/06/10/22/28/56/SEJARAH-KEMENTAN |language=Indonesian}}</ref>
The agricultural sector of Indonesia consists of:
* Large plantations, either owned by state or private companies; * Smallholder production modes, mostly traditional agricultural households.
The large plantations focus on export commodities such as palm oil and rubber, while the small scale farmers focus on horticultural commodities such as rice, soybeans, corn, fruits and vegetables in order to meet the food consumption of the local and regional population, .<ref name="IndoInvest"/>
Located in the [[tropic]]al region, Indonesia enjoys abundant rain and sunshine most of the time, which are important elements for agricultural products to thrive. The country possesses vast and abundant arable fertile soils. Indonesia is the world's major producer of a wide variety of agricultural tropical products and important agricultural commodities which include [[palm oil]], [[natural rubber]], [[Cocoa bean|cocoa]], [[coffee]], [[tea]], [[cassava]], [[rice]] and tropical [[spices]].<ref name="IndoInvest"/> [[File:Oil palm plantation in Cigudeg-03.jpg|thumb|right|Vast palm oil plantation in Indonesia. Currently, Indonesia is the world's largest producer of palm oil.]] At present, Indonesia is also the world's largest producer of [[palm oil]],<ref>{{cite web|work=Index Mundi|title=Palm Oil Production by Country in 1000 MT |url=http://www.indexmundi.com/agriculture/?commodity=palm-oil}}</ref> [[cloves]],<ref>{{cite web|work=FAOSTAT |title=Top Production, Cloves, 2012 |url=http://faostat.fao.org/site/339/default.aspx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713020710/http://faostat.fao.org/site/339/default.aspx |archivedate=2011-07-13 }}</ref> and [[cinnamon]],<ref>{{cite web|work=FAOSTAT |title=Top Production, Cinnamon (canella), 2012 |url=http://faostat.fao.org/site/339/default.aspx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713020710/http://faostat.fao.org/site/339/default.aspx |archivedate=2011-07-13 }}</ref> the 2nd largest producer of [[nutmeg]]<ref>{{cite web|work=FAOSTAT |title=Top Production, Nutmeg, mace and cardamoms, 2012 |url=http://faostat.fao.org/site/339/default.aspx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713020710/http://faostat.fao.org/site/339/default.aspx |archivedate=2011-07-13 }}</ref> [[natural rubber]]<ref name="faostat.fao.org default">{{cite web|work=FAOSTAT |title=Top Production, Rubber, natural, 2012 |url=http://faostat.fao.org/site/339/default.aspx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713020710/http://faostat.fao.org/site/339/default.aspx |archivedate=2011-07-13 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title= Chemical Economics Handbook, Natural Rubber|date= July 2014| work=IHS| url=https://www.ihs.com/products/natural-rubber-chemical-economics-handbook.html}}</ref> [[cassava]]<ref>{{cite web|work=FAOSTAT |title=Top Production, Cassava, 2012 |url=http://faostat.fao.org/site/339/default.aspx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713020710/http://faostat.fao.org/site/339/default.aspx |archivedate=2011-07-13 }}</ref> [[vanilla]]<ref>{{cite web|work=FAOSTAT |title=Top Production, Vanilla, 2012 |url=http://faostat.fao.org/site/339/default.aspx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713020710/http://faostat.fao.org/site/339/default.aspx |archivedate=2011-07-13 }}</ref> and [[coconut oil]],<ref>{{cite web|work=Index Mundi|title=Coconut Oil Production by Country in 1000 MT |url=http://www.indexmundi.com/agriculture/?commodity=coconut-oil&graph=production }}</ref> the 3rd largest producer of [[rice]]<ref>{{cite web|work=FAOSTAT |title=Top Production, Rice Paddy, 2012 |url=http://faostat.fao.org/site/339/default.aspx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713020710/http://faostat.fao.org/site/339/default.aspx |archivedate=2011-07-13 }}</ref> and [[Cocoa bean|cocoa]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Top 10 Cocoa Producing Countries |work=World Atlas|url=http://www.worldatlas.com/articles/top-10-cocoa-producing-countries.html}}</ref> the 4th largest producer of [[coffee]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Top 10 Coffee Producing Countries (2014)|work=World Atlas|url=http://www.worldatlas.com/articles/top-10-coffee-producing-countries-2014.html}}</ref> the 5th largest [[tobacco]] producer.<ref>{{cite web|work=Statista|title=Leading 10 tobacco producing countries worldwide in 2013 (in 1,000 metric tons) |url=http://www.statista.com/statistics/261173/leading-countries-in-tobacco-production/}}</ref> and the 6th largest producer of tea<ref name="WATea">{{cite web|title=The Worlds Top 10 Tea Producing Nations |work=World Atlas|url=http://www.worldatlas.com/articles/the-worlds-top-10-tea-producing-nations.html}}</ref>.
==History== In Indonesian history, agricultural pursuits spanned for some millennia with some traces still observable in some parts of the archipelago. The [[hunter-gatherer]] society still exist in interior Kalimantan (Indonesian Borneo) and Papua (Indonesian New Guinea) such as the [[Kombai people]],<ref>{{cite web| title = The Kombai | work = BBC | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/tribe/tribes/kombai/}}</ref> while they were a sophisticated rice-cultivating community, the remnants of Hindu-Buddhist polity can still be observed in [[Bali]] through their [[Subak (irrigation)|subak]] irrigation system.<ref name="UNESCO-Subak">{{cite web | title = Cultural Landscape of Bali Province: the Subak System as a Manifestation of the Tri Hita Karana Philosophy | work = UNESCO | url = http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1194}}</ref>
===Ancient era=== [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Bas-reliëf op de Borobudur TMnr 10027564.jpg|thumb|left|The bas-relief in 8th century [[Borobudur]] depicting a farmer plowing the field pulled by a buffalo.]] Agriculture in Indonesia started as a means to grow and provide food. Rice, [[coconut]], [[Arenga pinnata|sugar palm]], [[taro]], [[tuber]]s, [[shallot]]s and tropical fruits were among the earliest produce being cultivated in the archipelago. Evidence of wild rice cultivation on the island of Sulawesi dates back from 3000 BCE. [[Rice]] has been a staple food for Indonesians for a millennia<ref name="TAYLOR_8">{{cite book |last=Taylor|first=Jean Gelman|title=Indonesia: Peoples and Histories|publisher=Yale University Press|year=2003 |location= New Haven and London|url= |doi= |pages=8–9|isbn= 0-300-10518-5}}</ref> and holds a central place in [[Indonesian culture]] and [[Indonesian cuisine|cuisine]].
The importance of rice in Indonesian culture is demonstrated through the reverence of [[Dewi Sri]], the rice goddess of ancient Java and Bali.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jurnal.ugm.ac.id/ijg/article/view/4872|title=Land Management, the Myth of Dewi Sri, and the Balance of Javanese Cosmology, an Anthropogeographic Overview|author=Suwardi|work=UGM}}</ref> Traditionally, the agricultural cycles linked to rice cultivation were celebrated through rituals, such as [[Sundanese people|Sundanese]] ''[[Seren Taun]]'' or the "rice harvest festival." In [[Bali]], the traditional [[Subak (irrigation)|subak]] irrigation system was created to ensure that there is adequate water supply for rice paddies. The irrigation system was managed by priests and created around "[[Balinese temple#Types of pura|water temples]]".<ref name="UNESCO-Subak" /><ref name="Forshee-129" /> [[Indonesian architecture|Indonesian vernacular architecture]] also recognizes numbers of ''lumbung'' or [[rice barn]]s styles, such as Sundanese ''leuit'', Sasak style rice barn, Toraja's ''[[tongkonan]]'' shape, to Minangkabau's ''[[rangkiang]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museenkoeln.de/rautenstrauch-joest-museum/default.aspx?s=2044|title=The Museum's iconic hallmark – a Rice Barn from Indonesia|work=Rautenstrauch-Joest Museum|location=Köln}}</ref> Rice-growing shapes the landscape, is sold at markets, and is served in most meals.<ref name="Forshee-129">{{cite book | title = Culture and Customs of Indonesia, Culture and customs of Asia | first = Jill | last = Forshee | publisher = Greenwood Publishing Group | year = 2006 | isbn = 978-0-313-33339-2| page = 129 | url = https://books.google.co.id/books?id=y0xVkgXZOfUC&pg=PA129&dq=rice+Bali+irrigation+system+indonesia&hl=id&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjGlfGt6qjKAhWIc44KHfy1AXkQ6AEIOTAD#v=onepage&q=rice%20Bali%20irrigation%20system%20indonesia&f=false }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Indonesian Food: A Memorable Southeast Asian Cuisine | work = Living in Indonesia | url = http://www.expat.or.id/info/indonesianfood.html}}</ref>
While some panels of the bas-reliefs on [[Candi of Indonesia|temple]] walls, such as Borobudur and [[Prambanan]], describe agricultural activities, Javanese stone inscriptions which can be traced back from the 8th century, describes the king placing a levy on rice.<ref>{{cite book |last=Degroot|first=Véronique|title=Candi, Space and Landscape: A Study on the Distribution, Orientation and Spatial Organization of Central Javanese Temple Remains |year=2009 |url=https://books.google.co.id/books?id=u2HzduME8OcC&printsec=frontcover&hl=id#v=onepage&q&f=false |location=Leiden|publisher=Sidestone Press, Issue 38 of Mededelingen van het Rijksmuseum voor Volkenkunde |isbn=978-90-8890-039-6|page=100}}</ref> Next to rice, the bas-reliefs of Borobudur describe other indigenous agricultural products as well, like banana (''[[musa paradisiaca]]''), coconut (''[[Cocos nucifera]]''), sugarcane (''[[Saccharum officinarum]]'), Java apple (''[[Syzygium samarangense]]''), jackfruit (''[[Artocarpus heterophyllus]]''), durian (''[[Durio zibethinus]]'') and mangosteen (''[[Mangifera indica]]'').<ref>{{cite journal | title = Ekologi Manusia dan Lansekap Desa Di Indonesia | author = Ary Sulistyo | date = April 2, 2014 | work = IPLBI | language = Indonesian | url = http://iplbi.or.id/2014/04/ekologi-dan-lansekap-desa-di-indonesia/}}</ref>'' [[Image:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Beeld van Dewi Sri de rijstgodin TMnr 60016918.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Ancient statue of the rice goddess [[Dewi Sri]].]]
Local kingdoms in Indonesia were among the earliest polities to participate in global [[spice trade]]. The ancient maritime empires of [[Srivijaya]] (7th to 11th century) and [[Majapahit]] (13th to 15th century) for example, were actively involved in spice trade with China, India and the Middle East. Ports of [[Kingdom of Sunda|Sunda]] and [[Banten Sultanate|Banten]] were important centers of [[Black pepper|pepper]] trade back in the 14th to 17th centuries.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Jakarta Post|title=Museum Week to highlight spice trail |author=Novani Nugrahani|location=Jakarta | date= October 15, 2015 |url=http://m.thejakartapost.com/news/2015/10/15/museum-week-highlight-spice-trail.html}}</ref>
===Colonial era=== [[File:Muskatnuss.jpg|thumb|upright|left|[[Nutmeg]], for a long time was endemic only in [[Banda Islands]].]] Certain endemic Indonesian spices such as [[nutmeg]] which is indigenous to the Banda Islands and [[clove]]s were highly sought in the West, and prompted the European [[Age of Exploration]]. The [[Portuguese colonialism in Indonesia|Portuguese]] were the earliest Europeans who established their presence in the archipelago by the early 16th century. The Portuguese, through Spanish intermediaries, introduced the [[Americas|New World's]] products such as [[chili pepper]], [[maize]], [[papaya]], [[peanut]]s, potato, tomato, rubber and [[tobacco]] into the archipelago's soil.<ref>{{cite book | title = Culture and Customs of Indonesia, Culture and customs of Asia | first = Jill | last = Forshee | publisher = Greenwood Publishing Group | year = 2006 | isbn = 978-0-313-33339-2| page = 128 | url = https://books.google.co.id/books?id=y0xVkgXZOfUC&pg=PA128&dq=portuguese+chili+maize+peanuts+indonesia&hl=id&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi8pO-I6ajKAhWDj44KHQLfDhMQ6AEIIjAB#v=onepage&q=portuguese%20chili%20maize%20peanuts%20indonesia&f=false }}</ref>
The surge of the global spice trade was what led European traders reach the [[Indonesian archipelago]] who were in search for direct sources of valuable spices, at the same time, cut through middlemen in Asia (Arabs and Indian merchants) and in Europe (Italian merchants). By the early 17th century, [[Dutch East India Company]] (VOC) began to establish its influence within the archipelago, by building trading offices, warehouses and forts in [[Ambon, Maluku|Amboina]] and [[Batavia, Dutch East Indies|Batavia]].<ref>{{cite web | title = 602 Trade with the East: VOC | work = Rijkmuseum | url = https://www.rijksmuseum.nl/en/explore-the-collection/timeline-dutch-history/1602-trade-with-the-east-voc}}</ref> By then, VOC monopolized the spice commodity trade, especially pepper and [[nutmeg]],<ref>{{cite web | title = The Nutmeg Wars | author = Miss Cellania | date = August 6, 2012 | work = Neatorama | url =http://www.neatorama.com/2012/08/06/The-Nutmeg-Wars/}}</ref> and actively pursued its shares in intra-Asian trades with India and China. VOC further established [[sugar plantation|sugar plantations]] in Java.<ref>{{cite book | title = The Sugar Plantation in India and Indonesia: Industrial Production, 1770–2010, Studies in Comparative World History | first = Ulbe | last = Bosma | publisher = Cambridge University Press | year = 2013 | isbn = 978-1-107-03969-8 | page = 15 | url = https://books.google.co.id/books?id=ZaUaBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA15&lpg=PA15&dq=VOC+sugar+plantation+in+Java&source=bl&ots=OB_03ClMOS&sig=4XJXmGRGD68DCPC4Ho0uKjsgBlE&hl=id&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjUqa6F7KjKAhXCI44KHTfHD8YQ6AEIKDAC#v=onepage&q=VOC%20sugar%20plantation%20in%20Java&f=false }}</ref> [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Java koffiestruiken onder dadap met peperranken op een onderneming TMnr 10024162.jpg|thumb|right|Coffee plantation in Java, in early 20th century Dutch East Indies.]] By the turn of the 19th century, VOC was declared bankrupt and was nationalized by the Dutch as [[Dutch East Indies]]. This event officially marked the Dutch colonial period in the archipelago.<ref>{{cite web | title = 1820–1950 Indonesia and decolonisation | work = Rijkmuseum | url = https://www.rijksmuseum.nl/en/explore-the-collection/timeline-dutch-history/1820-1950-indonesia-and-decolonisation}}</ref> In the mid-19th century, the Dutch East Indies government implemented ''[[Cultivation System|cultuurstelsel]]'' which required a portion of agricultural production lands to be devoted to export crops. The cultivation system was enforced in Java and other parts of Indonesia by the Dutch colonial government between 1830 and 1870. Indonesian historians refer to it as ''Tanam Paksa'' ("Enforcement Planting"). The Dutch introduced numbers of [[cash crop]]s and commodities to create and establish an economic engine in its colony. Establishment of sugarcane, coffee, [[tea]], tobacco, quinine, rubber and palm oil plantations was also expanded in the colony.<ref name="Silaen">{{cite journal|author=Parulian Silaen|year=2006|title=The "Culture System" in Dutch Indonesia 1830–1870: How Rawls's Original Position Ethics were Violated|url=http://ro.uow.edu.au/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1143&context=commpapers|work=University of Wollongong}}</ref>
During the Dutch East Indies era, the agriculture sector was regulated by the ''Departement van Landbouw'' (1905), ''Departement van Landbouw, Nijverheid en Handel'' (1911) and ''Departement van Ekonomische Zaken'' (1934).<ref name="Kementan-Sejarah" />
===Republic era=== In 1942, [[Japanese occupation of the Dutch East Indies|Dutch East Indies fell]] under the control of the Japanese Empire. During the Japanese occupation, the agriculture sector was overseen by the ''Gunseikanbu Sangyobu''.<ref name="Kementan-Sejarah"/> During [[World War II]] (1942—1945), the Indies experienced hardships which included agricultural scarcity and famine. Rice yields and plantation commodities were controlled by the Japanese empire's military authority. The plantation business which was a major economic sector, was relatively shut down during the Pacific War and the ensuing [[Indonesian National Revolution|Indonesian war of independence]] (1945—1949). All efforts in the agricultural sector was focused in meeting basic needs for food (rice) and clothing (cotton). The Imperial Japanese authority attempted to increase rice and cotton production in the occupied Indies by mobilizing labor. However, scarcity of these essential commodities prevailed and resulted to famine and clothing shortage.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Shigeru Sato | title = Labour Relations in Japanese Occupied Indonesia | work = CLARA Working Paper, No. 8 |url = https://socialhistory.org/sites/default/files/docs/publications/clara-wp08.pdf}}</ref> [[File:Perkebunan kelapa sawit milik rakyat (1).JPG|thumb|right|Palm oil plantation in Kampar Regency, [[Riau]].]] The Indonesian Republic [[Proclamation of Indonesian Independence|declared its independence on 17 August 1945]]. Indonesia became a member of United Nation's [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] (FAO) in 1948. The partnership was strengthened with the opening of a FAO country office in 1978.<ref>{{cite web|title=Indonesia and FAO |work=FAO| url=http://www.fao.org/3/a-ax275e.pdf |type=pdf}}</ref> The agriculture sector of the republic has been supervised and regulated by the [[Ministry of Agriculture (Indonesia)|Indonesian Ministry of Agriculture]].<ref name="Kementan-Sejarah"/> The [[Republic of Indonesia|Indonesian Republic]] also nationalized many of its colonial economic infrastructures, institutions and businesses and inherited the agricultural system of its predecessor, the Dutch East Indies.
In the 1960s until the 1980s, the republic made every effort to develop a post-war agricultural sector and led to the sector's significant expansion. During the [[New Order (Indonesia)|Suharto era]], the government launched the [[transmigration program]] that relocated landless farmers from the overpopulated Java to the less populated Sumatra, Kalimantan, Sulawesi and Papua, thus expanded agricultural farms in the outer islands of the territory.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Indonesia's Transmigration Programme - An Update | work = Down To Earth | author = M.Adriana Sri Adhiati and Armin Bobsien (ed.) | date = July 2001 | url = http://www.downtoearth-indonesia.org/old-site/ctrans.htm}}</ref>
The most significant indicator of growth is the expansion of palm oil plantations, which became the new form of transmigration program.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Oil Palm and the New Transmigration in Indonesiaː Examples from Kalimantan | first = Lesley | last = Potter | work = Australian National University, Resource Management in Asia Pacific Program | url = https://crawford.anu.edu.au/rmap/pdf/seminars//seminar_paper_6091.pdf }}</ref> Currently, Indonesia is the world's largest producer of palm oil and the leading producer of coffee, rubber and cocoa. However, Indonesia still has vast tracts of idle lands which can potentially be developed into farmlands. These cover 40 million hectares of degraded forest areas that have turned into grasslands after being abandoned by logging concessionaires.
Agricultural commodities are known for its economic resilience and are among the first to recover from the impacts of global financial meltdown. With a large number of its population still working in the agriculture segment, Indonesia has great potentials of attracting foreign investments.<ref name="JP-Agri">{{cite news|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2010/11/14/the-rise-agriculture-and-indonesia%E2%80%99s-future.html|title=The rise of agriculture and Indonesia's future|last=Simbolon|first=Johannes|date=November 14, 2010|accessdate=7 December 2015|location=Jakarta}}</ref>
==Food products== The agriculture sector plays a vital role in food production and [[food security]] and in supplying the needs of a huge Indonesian population.<ref>{{cite web | title = Indonesia | work = Food Security Portal | url = http://www.foodsecurityportal.org/indonesia}}</ref>
===Rice=== {{main article|Rice production in Indonesia}} [[File:Rice terraces in Jatiluwih, Tabanan Regency, Bali, Indonesia.jpg|thumb|right|Rice paddy terraces in [[Bali]].]] [[Rice]] is a staple food in the Indonesian diet,<ref name="TAYLOR_8"/> as typical [[Cuisine of Indonesia|Indonesian meal]] consists of richly flavored side dishes, meat or poultry and vegetables, surrounding a pile of [[steamed rice]]. Indonesia is the 3rd largest rice producer in the world after China and India. However, because of Indonesia's large population, the rice it produces is consumed internally. To ensure food security, the government fills the gap by importing from neighboring countries like Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jokowi finally agrees to import rice from Thailand, Vietnam |newspaper=The Jakarta Post |location= Jakarta | date= October 22, 2015 |url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2015/10/22/jokowi-finally-agrees-import-rice-thailand-vietnam.html}}</ref>
===Horticulture=== [[File:Ubud Bali Indonesia Pura-Dalem-Puri-01.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Fruit offering in Bali.]] [[Horticulture]], which covers [[fruit]]s and [[vegetable]]s production, holds an important role in the local Indonesian economy and in the attainment of food security. Indonesia possesses a variety of horticultural products. Its native fruits include [[durian]], [[mangosteen]], [[rambutan]], [[salak]], [[banana]], [[jackfruit]], [[mango]], ''[[Spondias dulcis|kedondong]]'', ''[[Syzygium samarangense|jambu air]]'', ''[[Antidesma bunius|buni]]'', ''[[Syzygium cumini|jamblang]]'' and ''[[Sandoricum koetjape|kecapi]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=10 Great Balinese Fruits | work=Bali Indonesia Magazine|url=http://www.bali-indonesia.com/magazine/10-great-fruits-in-bali.htm}}</ref> The bulk of fruits and vegetables needed by consumers are supplied by local traditional farmers. The products prices are highly dependent on seasonal availability and proximity to production centers, due to transportation and cargo infrastructure restrictions. As a result, prices of horticulture products vary greatly throughout Indonesia. Prices might be cheaper in [[Bandung]] and [[Bukittinggi]] as they are closer to horticulture farms but are significantly more expensive in [[Pekanbaru]] and [[Balikpapan]] which are located far from production centers. Recently, owing to a varied Indonesian topography, non-tropical horticultural products such as [[apple]], [[strawberry]], [[Honeydew (melon)|honeydew]], [[grape]]s and [[Pitaya|dragon fruit]] are grown in the cooler mountainous region of Indonesia. The mountainous region around [[Malang]] in East Java is the production center for apple and dragon fruit, while those around Bandung in West Java are the production centers for strawberry, honeydew and mushroom.<ref>{{cite news|title=Picking strawberries in Lembang | newspaper=The Jakarta Post Travel | author= Vira Zoelfikar | date= October 21, 2013 |url=http://www.jakpost.travel/news/-picking-strawberries-in-lembang-5qF8fWtTM6ZCjBoY.html}}</ref> [[File:Pasar Terapung, Siring.jpg|thumb|right|Floating market in Siring, [[Banjarmasin]].]] Despite its being home to the world's 4th largest population making it a huge market for horticultural products, the horticultural sector in Indonesia is deemed as under-performing which leads to the necessity of importing fruits and vegetables.<ref name="GBG-Horticulture">{{cite web| title=Organic Growth – Horticulture in Indonesia |work=Global Business Guide |url=http://www.gbgindonesia.com/en/agriculture/article/2014/organic_growth_horticulture_in_indonesia.php |accessdate= 7 December 2015}}</ref> Indonesian horticulture farmers face a problematic situation - the imported horticultural products are often cheaper than the locally produced horticultural products.<ref name="II-Horticulture">{{cite web|title=Indonesia's Horticultural Products and the Trade Ministry's Regulatory Framework | date=6 May 2013 |work= Indonesia Investment |url=http://www.indonesia-investments.com/id/business/business-columns/indonesias-horticultural-products-and-trade-ministrys-new-regulatory-framework/item714 |accessdate= 7 December 2015}}</ref> Compared to neighboring countries with a well-developed horticultural sector like [[Thailand]], Indonesia has much to improve. Currently, Indonesia imports much of its horticultural needs from Thailand (durian, carrot and chili pepper), China ([[garlic]], orange and pear) and from the United States (soybean and apple). To protect local farmers, the Indonesian government applied protectionist policies on import settings for horticultural products, as well as restricting ports of entry.<ref>{{cite news|title=Indonesia-Thailand bahas kebijakan impor produk hortikultura |date= 7 October 2013| author=Ida Nurcahyani|newspaper=Antara| url=http://www.antaranews.com/berita/399316/indonesia-thailand-bahas-kebijakan-impor-produk-hortikultura |language=Indonesian}}</ref> [[File:Spices for Indonesian food.jpg|thumb|right|Various [[Bumbu (seasoning)|Indonesian spices]].]] [[Spice]] is an essential element in [[Indonesian cuisine]]. In [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]], spice is called ''rempah'', while the mixture of spices is called ''[[Bumbu (seasoning)|bumbu]]'', they are chopped finely or ground into paste using traditional stone [[mortar and pestle]], and spread over vegetables, meat, poultry, fish and seafood to add aroma and taste.<ref name="Herbs and Spices">{{cite web|title=Herbs and Spices, The most important part of Indonesian cooking| work=Discover Java and Bali |url=http://www.discover-java-and-bali.com/herbs-and-spices.html |accessdate=8 December 2015}}</ref> Known throughout the world as the "Spice Islands", the Indonesian islands of [[Maluku Islands|Maluku]] contributed to the introduction of its native spices to the world. Spices such as ''pala'' ([[nutmeg|nutmeg/mace]]), ''cengkeh'' ([[clove]]), ''daun'' ''pandan'' ([[Pandanus amaryllifolius|Pandan leaves]]), ''kluwek'' ([[Pangium edule]]) and ''laos'' ([[galangal]]) are native to Indonesia. However, surprisingly nutmeg, mace and cloves are seldomly used in Indonesian cuisine.<ref>{{cite web |title= Indonesia: Spices |work= Global Gourmet |url= http://www.globalgourmet.com/destinations/indonesia/indospice.html#axzz3thR9yZIo |accessdate= 8 December 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20151208104325/http://www.globalgourmet.com/destinations/indonesia/indospice.html#axzz3thR9yZIo |archive-date= 2015-12-08 |dead-url= yes |df= }}</ref>
It is likely that ''lada hitam'' ([[black pepper]]), ''kunyit'' ([[turmeric]]), ''sereh'' ([[lemongrass]]), ''salam koja'' ([[curry leaf]]), ''bawang merah'' ([[shallot]]), ''kayu manis'' ([[cinnamon]]), ''kemiri'' ([[candlenut]]), ''ketumbar'' ([[coriander]]), and ''asam jawa'' ([[tamarind]]) were introduced from India or mainland Southeast Asia, while ''jahe'' ([[ginger]]), ''daun bawang'' ([[scallion]]s) and ''bawang putih'' ([[garlic]]) were introduced from China. Those spices from mainland Asia were introduced early, in ancient times, thus they became integral ingredients in Indonesian cuisine. While the [[New World]] spices such as [[chili pepper]] and [[tomato]] were introduced by Portuguese and Spanish traders during the [[age of exploration]] in the 16th century.<ref name="Herbs and Spices"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spicesofindia.co.uk/acatalog/Bumbu-Bali.html |title=Bumbu|work= Spices of India}}</ref>
==Commodities==
===Palm oil=== {{main article|Palm oil production in Indonesia}} [[File:Buah kelapa sawit (46).JPG|thumb|right|Palm oil bunch.]] Indonesia is both the world's biggest producer and consumer of the commodity, providing about half the world supply. [[Oil palm]] plantations stretch across 6 million hectares. Palm oil is the essential ingredients to produces [[cooking oil]], as well as other food and cosmetics products. The country also aimed to be the largest palm-based [[biofuel]] production center.<ref name=McClanahan2013>{{cite news|last=McClanahan|first=Paige|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2013/sep/11/indonesia-palm-oil-destroy-forests|title=Can Indonesia increase palm oil output without destroying its forest? Environmentalists doubt the world's biggest palm oil producer can implement ambitious plans without damaging woodland|accessdate=22 September 2013|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=11 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Indonesia Palm Oil Production by Year|work=Index Mundi| url=http://www.indexmundi.com/agriculture/?country=id&commodity=palm-oil&graph=production}}</ref>
===Coconut=== {{main article|Coconut production in Indonesia}} Coconut plays an important role in [[Indonesian cuisine]] as well as its economy. [[Coconut milk]] is an important common ingredients in numbers of Indonesian favourites, including ''[[rendang]]'' and ''[[Soto (food)|soto]]''. According to figures published in December 2009 by the [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] of the [[United Nations]], it is the world's second largest producer of coconuts, producing 15,319,500 tonnes in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://faostat.fao.org/site/567/DesktopDefault.aspx?PageID=567#ancor |title=Food And Agriculture Organization of the United Nations |work=Economic And Social Department: The Statistical Division |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130114151638/http://faostat.fao.org/site/567/DesktopDefault.aspx?PageID=567 |archivedate=2013-01-14 }}</ref>
===Rubber=== [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Het aftappen van een rubberboom op een plantage van Goodyear bij Siantar TMnr 20018369.jpg|thumb|right|Rubber tapping near Siantar in North Sumatra in 1993.]] Indonesian rubber industry take its root in colonial Dutch East Indies; in the early 20th century the rubber plantation in the colony was booming, largely owed to the advent of natural rubber tire industry to supply the growing [[automotive industry]] in the United States and Europe. Currently, Indonesia's rubber production is the world's second-largest after Thailand.<ref name="faostat.fao.org default"/> Natural rubber is an important export commodity that earn foreign exchange, with increasing production trend. In fact, [[ASEAN]] nations are among the largest natural rubber producers; the combined rubber yield of three ASEAN members — Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia — accounts for nearly 66 percent of global total rubber production. However, compared to neighbouring countries, Indonesia's productivity level is lower (1,080 kg/ha), compared to Thailand (1,800 kg/ha), Vietnam (1,720 kg/ha) and Malaysia (1,510 kg/ha). Smallholder farmers in Indonesia retain for about 85 percent of total rubber estates, which suggests the minor role of government and large private estates in Indonesian rubber industry. Another problem is the lack of rubber processing facilities and manufacturing industry. In Indonesia, about half of the natural rubber that is absorbed internally goes to the [[tire]] manufacturing industry, followed by rubber gloves, rubber thread, footwear, retread tires, medical gloves, rubber carpets and various rubber tools.<ref>{{cite web | work=Indonesia Investments | title= Rubber Industry Indonesia: Challenges and Opportunities | date= 22 April 2015 |url=http://www.indonesia-investments.com/id/news/news-columns/rubber-industry-indonesia-challenges-and-opportunities/item5490}}</ref>
===Coffee=== {{main article|Coffee production in Indonesia}} [[File:Javanese Kopi Tubruk.jpg|thumb|right|A cup of Java coffee.]] In 2014, Indonesia was the fourth largest producer of [[coffee]]. Coffee in Indonesia began with its [[Dutch East Indies|colonial history]], and has played an important part in the growth of the country. Indonesia's geographic location is considered as ideal for coffee plantations. It is located near the equator and with numerous mountainous regions across the islands which creates suitable micro-climates for the growth and production of coffee.<ref name="ico.org">{{cite web|title=Total production by all exporting countries| work=International Coffee Organization| url=http://www.ico.org/prices/po-production.pdf|type=pdf}}</ref>
Indonesia produced an estimated 540,000 metric tons of coffee in 2014.<ref name="ico.org"/> Of this total, estimated 154,800 tons was required for domestic consumption in the 2013–2014 financial year.<ref>USDA GAIN (2014). Indonesia Coffee Annual 2014, Global Agricultural Information Network (GAIN), USDA Foreign Agricultural Service. Available at: http://gain.fas.usda.gov/Recent%20GAIN%20Publications/Coffee%20Annual_Jakarta_Indonesia_5-14-2014.pdf</ref> Of the exports, 25% are [[Coffea arabica|arabica]] beans; the balance is [[Robusta coffee|robusta]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Ico.org|url=http://www.ico.org/trade_statistics.asp|title=Trade Statistics|accessdate=2008-08-07}}</ref>
===Tea=== Indonesia is the world sixth largest [[tea]] producer. Tea production in Indonesia began in the 18th century, introduced by the Dutch as cash crop. Indonesia produced 150,100 tonnes of tea in 2013. However, 65% of that was exported from the country, which suggests Indonesians relatively low tea consumption. Tea production in Indonesian focused mainly on [[black tea]], although small amounts of green are also produced. Moreover, many Indonesian tea varieties are not well known globally, since much of the Indonesian tea is used in blends; mixed with other teas.<ref name="WATea"/>
===Tobacco=== {{main article|Tobacco products in Indonesia|Smoking in Indonesia}} Indonesia is the fifth largest [[tobacco]] producer in the world, and also the fifth largest tobacco market in the world, and in 2008 over 165 billion cigarettes were sold in the country.<ref name="TFC">{{Cite web|url=http://tobaccofreecenter.org/resources_country/indonesia|title=Indonesia|publisher=Tobacco Free Center|accessdate=September 3, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100611004049/http://tobaccofreecenter.org/resources_country/indonesia|archive-date=2010-06-11|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
==Environmental issues== As agricultural pursuits altered the natural landscapes; from [[rainforest]], peat lands and swamps into arable lands, certainly it poses natural and environmental consequences. Environmental problems such as deforestation and forest and plantation fires, caused by forestry and agricultural sectors in Indonesia, continues to be a persisting problem that need to be addressed and solved.<ref>{{cite web | title = 4 Ways to Stop Indonesia's Forest Fires | author = Bustar Maitar | date = November 1, 2015 | work = Greenpeace |url = http://www.greenpeace.org/usa/4-ways-to-stop-indonesias-forest-fires/}}</ref>
===Deforestation=== {{main article|Deforestation in Indonesia}} [[File:Riau deforestation 2006.jpg|thumb|right|Deforestation in [[Riau]] (2006).]] The [[deforestation]] in Indonesia is caused by [[logging industry]], either legal or illegal, and in turn also contributed by the conversion of natural rainforest into agricultural lands, especially palm oil plantation.<ref>{{cite web | title=Background information on Indonesia, deforestation and illegal logging | work=ABC | year=2002 | url=http://www.abc.net.au/4corners/content/2002/timber_mafia/resources/resources_indonesia.htm | access-date=2015-12-06 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160116043142/http://www.abc.net.au/4corners/content/2002/timber_mafia/resources/resources_indonesia.htm | archive-date=2016-01-16 | dead-url=yes | df= }}</ref> Clearing rainforests for oil palm plantations has destroyed critical habitat for endangered species like rhinos, elephants, tigers and orangutans, which have all been pushed to the verge of extinction. This practice has raised international scrutiny on palm oil industry in Indonesia, especially from [[World Wide Fund for Nature]], and raised the demand on sustainable palm oil production and certification.<ref>{{cite web|title=Palm oil and deforestation |work=WWF |url=http://www.wwf.org.au/our_work/saving_the_natural_world/forests/palm_oil/palm_oil_and_deforestation/}}</ref>
===Forest and plantation fires=== {{See also|Southeast Asian haze|1997 Southeast Asian haze|2015 Southeast Asian haze}}
Indonesian [[palm oil]] plantations' poor practice and poor environmental responsibility, has led to massive haze problem annually. Since 1997 Indonesia has been struggling to contain forest fires, especially on the islands of [[Sumatra]] and [[Kalimantan]]. Haze occurs annually during the [[dry season]] and is largely caused by illegal agricultural fires due to [[slash-and-burn]] practices in Indonesia, especially in the provinces of [[South Sumatra]] and [[Riau]] on Indonesia's [[Sumatra]] island, and [[Kalimantan]] on Indonesian [[Borneo]].<ref name=SOB>{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/minister-blasts-execs-of-firm-that-denied-burning-forest|title=Minister blasts execs of firm that denied burning forest|first1=Wahyudi|last1=Soeriaatmadja|work=[[The Straits Times]]|accessdate=13 October 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151013022700/http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/minister-blasts-execs-of-firm-that-denied-burning-forest|archivedate=13 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=What causes South East Asia's haze?|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-34265922|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=26 September 2015|date=16 September 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151003010304/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-34265922|archivedate=3 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Southeast Asia's haze: what's behind the annual outbreaks?|url=http://news.asiaone.com/news/singapore/southeast-asias-haze-whats-behind-annual-outbreaks|publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]]|accessdate=26 September 2015|date=17 September 2015|archivedate=27 September 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150927032422/http://news.asiaone.com/news/singapore/southeast-asias-haze-whats-behind-annual-outbreaks}}</ref> The haze that occurred in [[1997 Southeast Asian haze|1997]] was one of the most severe; dense hazes occurred again in [[2005 Malaysian haze|2005]], [[2006 Southeast Asian haze|2006]], [[2009 Southeast Asian haze|2009]], [[2013 Southeast Asian haze|2013]], and the worst was in [[2015 Southeast Asian haze|2015]], killing dozens of Indonesians as a result of respiratory illnesses and road accidents due to poor visibility.<ref>{{cite news|title=Haze kills 10 people, leaves 503,874 with respiratory ailments| newspaper=The Jakarta Post| date=October 24, 2015 |url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2015/10/24/haze-kills-10-people-leaves-503874-with-respiratory-ailments-agency.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.okezone.com/read/2015/09/18/340/1217052/gara-gara-kabut-asap-biker-tewas-tabrak-mobil-pemadam|title=Gara-Gara Kabut Asap, Biker Tewas Tabrak Mobil Pemadam|language=Indonesian|author=Banda Haruddin Tanjung|publisher=Okezone|date=18 September 2015|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.balikpapanpos.co.id/berita/detail/173903-akibat-kabut-asap-dua-tewas.html|title=Akibat Kabut Asap, Dua Tewas (Laka Tunggal, Tabrak Tiang Listrik)|language=Indonesian|publisher=Balikpapan Pos|date=29 September 2015|accessdate=29 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151008165216/http://www.balikpapanpos.co.id/berita/detail/173903-akibat-kabut-asap-dua-tewas.html|archive-date=2015-10-08|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.liputan6.com/read/2317496/tewas-akibat-tercekik-asap|title=Tewas Akibat 'Tercekik' Asap|language=Indonesian|author=Bangun Santoso|publisher=Liputan 6|date=14 September 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite AV media|url=http://video.metrotvnews.com/play/2015/10/04/437506/ini-daftar-korban-tewas-akibat-kabut-asap|title=Ini Daftar Korban Tewas Akibat Kabut Asap|author=AMS|language=Indonesian|medium=video|time=10:24|publisher=Metro TV News|date=4 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015}}</ref>

revision.comment: /* Biography */HTTP→HTTPS for [[Find a Grave]], replaced: http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid= → https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/ using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox musical artist | name = Akiko Futaba | image = 二葉あき子.jpg | caption = Akiko Futaba in 1930 | image_size = 225 | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Yoshie Kato | alias = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1915|02|02|mf=yes}} |birth_place =[[Hiroshima]], [[Hiroshima Prefecture]], [[Japan]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2011|08|16|1915|02|02}}
[[Hiroshima]], [[Hiroshima Prefecture]], [[Japan]] | origin = | instrument = | genre = [[Ryūkōka]] | occupation = [[Singer]] | years_active = 1936–2003 | label = [[Columbia Music Entertainment]] | associated_acts = | website = }} {{nihongo|'''Akiko Futaba'''|二葉 あき子|''Futaba Akiko''|born '''Yoshie Kato''' ({{nihongo2|加藤 芳江}}); February 2, 1915 – August 16, 2011}} was a Japanese popular music (''[[ryūkōka]]'') singer. At of the end of [[World War II]], she was one of the most popular female singers in Japan, competing with [[Hamako Watanabe]] and [[Noriko Awaya]].{{cite web|url=http://www.news.janjan.jp/column/0608/0608239960/1.php |script-title=ja:古き花園のブルースを歌う・二葉あき子 |author=Kikuchi, Kiyomaro |publisher=[[JANJAN]] |date=2006-08-24 |accessdate=2009-04-24 |language=ja |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071110184453/http://www.news.janjan.jp/column/0608/0608239960/1.php |archivedate=2007-11-10 }} In addition, she took part in the ''[[Kōhaku Uta Gassen]]'', one of Japan's most famous annual musical television shows, ten times.{{cite web|url=http://www.nikkansports.com/news2/entert2/2001kouhaku/history-10.html|title=10th Kōhaku Uta Gassen|publisher=[[Nikkan Sports]]|accessdate=2009-04-24|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090325155811/http://www.nikkansports.com/news2/entert2/2001kouhaku/history-10.html|archivedate=25 March 2009|deadurl=yes|language=ja|df=}} ==Biography== She was born in the city of [[Hiroshima]], and raised in [[Miyoshi, Hiroshima|Miyoshi city]], [[Hiroshima Prefecture]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hiroshima-bunka.jp/english/detail/093.html|title=Izumo Road and Funo Juku (post town)|publisher=[[Hiroshima Prefecture]]|accessdate=2009-04-24}} She graduated from the [[Tokyo University of the Arts|Tokyo Music School]]. Impressed by Takeo Masunaga (also known as [[Ichiro Fujiyama]]) at a performance held by the music school, she debuted in 1936. Her famous song {{nihongo|"Furuki Hanazono"|古き花園|lit. "Old Flower Garden"}} was released in 1939. On August 6, 1945, she narrowly avoided the [[Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|atomic bombing of Hiroshima]] because she was riding a train traveling through a tunnel at the time of the explosion. She ceased activity as a singer in 2003, and retired in Hiroshima Prefecture. She died in Hiroshima on 16 August 2011.[https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/75171282 Akiko Futaba] == Discography == *{{nihongo|''Ano Yume Kono Yume''|あの夢この夢|That Dream, This Dream}} : 1936 *{{nihongo|''Otome Jūku''|乙女十九|Girl at the Age of 19}} : 1937 *{{nihongo|''Furuki Hanazono''|古き花園|Old Flower Garden}} : 1939 *{{nihongo|''Ano Hana Kono Hana''|あの花この花|That Flower, This Flower}} : 1940 *{{nihongo|''Wakarete mo''|別れても|Even If We're Apart}} : 1946 *{{nihongo|''Otome Gokoro wa''|乙女心は|A Girl's Heart Is}} : 1946 *{{nihongo|''Francesca no Kane''|[[:ja:フランチェスカの鐘|フランチェスカの鐘]]|The Bells of Francesca}} : 1948 *{{nihongo|''Yume yo Mō Ichido''|夢よもういちど|Once Again, Dream}} : 1949 *{{nihongo|''Hoshi no Tameiki''|星のためいき|Star's Sigh}} : 1950 ==References== ==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=1728435|name=Akiko Futaba}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Futaba, Akiko}} [[Category:1915 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:Hibakusha]] [[Category:Japanese female singers]] [[Category:Tokyo Music School alumni]] [[Category:Musicians from Hiroshima]] [[Category:20th-century Japanese musicians]] [[Category:20th-century women singers]] {{Japan-singer-stub}}

{{distinguish|Aqua Augusta (Rome)}} [[Image:CapoMiseno.jpg|thumb|View of Capo Miseno at [[Misenum]]]] [[File:Pozzuoli aqueduct.jpg|thumb|twin aqueduct tunnels at Pozzuoli]] [[File:Ponti Rossi Napoli.jpg|thumb|Ponti Rossi]]
The '''Aqua Augusta''', or '''Serino Aqueduct''' ({{lang-it|Acquedotto Romano del Serino}}), was one of the largest, most complex and costliest [[Aqueduct (Roman)|aqueduct]] systems in the [[Roman Empire|Roman]] world; it supplied water to at least eight ancient cities in the Bay of [[Naples]] including [[Pompeii]] and [[Herculaneum]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.romanaqueducts.info/aquasite/serino/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2007-08-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927064500/http://www.romanaqueducts.info/aquasite/serino/ |archive-date=2007-09-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> This aqueduct was unlike any other of its time, being a regional network rather than being focussed on one urban centre.<ref>Historical development of the Augustan Aqueduct in Southern Italy: twenty centuries of works from Serino to Naples; G. De Feo and R.M.A Napoli, Water Science & Technology Water Supply, March 2007</ref>
==Route of the aqueduct== The route of the aqueduct<ref>Aqua Augusta - Serino (Italy): http://www.romanaqueducts.info/aquasite/</ref> is well known thanks to the writings of two Italian engineers<ref>Pietro Antonio Lettieri 1560, Felice Abate 1840, Abate 1842, Abate 1862, Abate 1864.</ref> who were asked to see if it could be brought back in use as the main water supply of Naples in the 16th and 19th centuries.
There were ten branches, seven of which were for cities while three were for some of the numerous luxurious villas in this area popular with rich Romans, such as the Villa Pollio at [[Posillipo]].<ref>P. Papinius Statius, Silvae Book II: A Commentary, Harm-Jan Van Dam - 1984, {{ISBN|9004071105}}</ref> Including the branches, the total length of the aqueduct was approximately {{Convert|140|km|mi|abbr=off}}, making it the longest Roman aqueduct, with the possible exception of the [[Gadara Aqueduct]], until the 5th century AD when the [[Valens Aqueduct]] was extended in [[Constantinople]]. The Aqua Augusta was one of the most difficult and costly aqueducts ever constructed by an ancient civilisation.<ref>The Aqua Augusta and control of water resources in the Bay of Naples Duncan Keenan-Jones, Macquarie University, Australasian Society for Classical Studies Conference 31, Perth, Australia 2010</ref> Despite its size and complexity, the Augusta is today largely unknown as a major monument because most of it is underground.
The aqueduct's source, the Fons Augusteus (now known as Acquaro-Pelosi), was in the [[Terminio]]-Tuoro mountains near the modern town of [[Serino]] not far from the city of [[Avellino]] and at 376 metres above sea level. One of its main terminations was the enormous [[Piscina Mirabilis]] at the naval base and port of [[Misenum]].
Since the aqueduct traversed such a distance, many difficulties were encountered when building it; two-kilometre-long tunnels were cut through mountains, and there was ground movement near the coast due to volcanoes and a sea crossing was needed to the island of [[Nisida]].
There is evidence that a large number of private users were members of the Rome senatorial class. In Rome, a letter from the emperor was required to gain a private connection and so it seems that imperial favour was also a factor in accessing the Augusta's water. __NOTOC__
==History== The Emperor [[Augustus]] (or more likely his close friend and ally [[Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa|Agrippa]]) had the Aqua Augusta built between 30 and 20 BC.<ref name="Hodge, A.T">Hodge, A.T., Roman Aqueducts & Water Supply'', 2nd ed. London: Duckworth.</ref>
During the war with [[Sextus Pompey|Pompeius]], Augustus ordered the construction of the [[Portus Julius]] harbour complex just west of Puteoli. Later, this harbour was seen as less ideal for the navy because of silting problems and a new major naval base was built further west at Misenum, where two lakes were connected to become the basis of the western Mediterranean war fleet. Large quantities of fresh water were needed for the base itself and for the ships, which must have been one of the reasons why Augustus had the new aqueduct built.<ref>Passchier, C.W. and Schram, W.D. (2005). Serino (Italy). Aqua Augusta</ref> The main cistern filled by the aqueduct is the Piscina Mirabilis in Ba ́coli (Misenum).
Such a major monument required constant maintenance; there were major repairs in the Flavian period (1st century AD) with the addition of parallel tunnels and the Emperor [[Constantine the Great|Constantine]] also engaged in a massive restoration documented on an inscription tablet<ref>{{cite web|url=http://db.edcs.eu/epigr/epi_einzel.php?s_sprache=it&p_belegstelle=AE+1939,+00151&r_sortierung=Belegstelle|title=Epigraphik Datenbank|website=Db.edcs.eu|accessdate=8 September 2018}}</ref> discovered in Serino and dated to AD 324. The destinations listed are: *[[Nola]] *[[Acerra]]e *[[Atella]] *[[Naples]] *[[Pozzuoli]] *[[Baiae]] *[[Cumae]] *[[Misenum]]
The cities of [[Pompeii]], [[Herculaneum]] and [[Stabiae]] were also originally supplied by the aqueduct but being destroyed and covered by the eruption of [[Vesuvius]] in 79 AD they did not appear on this list. [[File:Castellum Aquae Pompeii 271.jpg|thumb|The spur from the Aqua Augusta entering the castellum aquae in [[Pompeii]]]] The next major eruption in 472 AD left the aqueduct covered in ash and 3.5 km of the duct collapsed because of this. This cut off the supply of water to all the towns except Nola and Acerrae. The poor administrative and economic situation in Campania at this time, and Italy in general, prevented major repairs to the Augusta. Written references to aqueducts in Naples after this time only refer to other aqueducts that were now in the area.
In modern times, parts of the aqueduct, in addition to the Piscina Mirabilis were vital to the region's survival during World War II. Many locals used the areas as air-raid shelters.
==Visible Remains== There are few visible remains of the aqueduct today, although much of it still exists below ground. Traces of the original structure may be found at a number of sites in and around Naples.
These include:
* the two parallel [[:it:Ponti Rossi|Ponti Rossi]] aqueduct bridges * a section next to the [[Crypta Neapolitana]] in the Parco Vergiliano at Piedigrotta where it occupied a parallel tunnel * the well-preserved [[Piscina Mirabilis]] at Misenum. This is one of the largest such terminal reservoirs on an aqueduct known in the [[Roman Empire]] and survives almost intact to this day. It was probably intended as a strategic water resource for the naval base, especially if the base had been besieged. [[Image:Piscina mirabilis3.jpg|thumb|The [[Piscina Mirabilis]]]]
== Literary allusions == It features prominently in the novel ''[[Pompeii (novel)|Pompeii]]'' by [[Robert Harris (novelist)|Robert Harris]], whose [[protagonist]] is a water engineer ("Aquarius") sent from [[Rome]] to maintain the aqueduct in AD 79 during the time around the eruption of [[Mount Vesuvius]].

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox person | pre-nominals = Dr | name = Asha Kasliwal | post-nominals = MBBS, FRCOG, FFSRH, MD (O&G) | residence = the UK | nationality = British Indian | known_for = President of the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) }}
'''Dr Asha Kasliwal,''' [[Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery|MBBS]], [[FRCOG]], [[FFSRH]], MD ([[Obstetrics and gynaecology|O&G]]) is the President of the [[Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare]], also known as FSRH.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.fsrh.org/authors/dr-asha-kasliwal/|title=authors - Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare|website=www.fsrh.org|language=en|access-date=2018-02-22}}</ref>
== Education == Dr Asha Kasliwal immigrated to [[United Kingdom|the UK]] in 1995 after studying in [[Mumbai]], India and working in [[Oman]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.rcplondon.ac.uk/projects/outputs/women-medicine-asha-kasliwal-and-anandibai-gopal-joshi|title=Women in medicine: Asha Kasliwal and Anandibai Gopal Joshi|date=2017-10-03|work=RCP London|access-date=2018-02-22}}</ref> After graduation, she was a part of the [[Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists|Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (RCOG]]) trainees committee as a representative of overseas doctors.<ref name=":2" />
Kasliwal's main areas of academic and medical focus are care and clinical standards quality, gynaecology within communities, hormone replacement therapy for women undergoing menopause, pregnancy and abortion, and the commissioning of accessible contraceptive and sexual health resources.<ref name=":0" />
Kasliwal was inspired to pursue medicine by [[Anandi Gopal Joshi|Anandibai Gopal Joshi]], one of the earliest known Indian women physicians.<ref name=":2" />
== Career == Alongside being the President of FSRH, other titles that Kasliwal has are: Consultant in Community Gynaecology and Reproductive Health Care, Clinical Director for Manchester's Contraception and Sexual Health service, and Clinical Director for the South Manchester Community Gynaecology service.<ref name=":0" /> She is also a specialist member of the "Quality Standards for Contraceptive Services" committee within [[National Institute for Health and Care Excellence|the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE)]], and has been featured in the Royal College of Physicians exhibition.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rcplondon.ac.uk/projects/women-medicine|title=Women in medicine|date=2017-09-19|work=RCP London|access-date=2018-02-22}}</ref>
Before becoming the president of FSRH, Kasliwal was the Vice President of Quality and Standards in the FSRH from September 2014 to her election as president of the group, and the Clinical Director & Consultant in Community Gynaecology and Reproductive Health.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
=== As President of FSRH === Succeeding Dr Chris Wilkson's five year term, Kasliwal became the President of FSRH on 28 July 2016, after being elected to the position in May of 2016.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.fsrh.org/news/dr-asha-kasliwal-announced-as-fsrh-president-elect/|title=Dr Asha Kasliwal announced as FSRH President - Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare|website=www.fsrh.org|language=en|access-date=2018-02-22}}</ref>
Her priorities within this office include: * Continue FSRH's engagement with multiple organisations, such as the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH), [[Royal College of General Practitioners|RCGP]], and RCOG * Continue to support Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (SRH) professionals and commissioners through providing quality standards of care and training * Expand the inclusivity of all FDRH committees, but particularly nurses and [[General practitioner|General Practitioners]] * FSRH promotion * Increase the accessibility, availability, and quality of reproductive and sexual healthcare <ref name=":1" />
== See also == * [[Women in medicine]] * [[Sexual and reproductive health and rights]] *
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * Dr [https://www.nexis.com/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=5R5R-WH31-JBVM-Y2WJ&csi=280434&oc=00240&perma=true Asha Kasliwal's article "Scotland can be a global leader on sexual health" from ''The Times'' (London), 14 December 2017] * [https://www.fsrh.org/blogs/dr-asha-kasliwal-fsrh-president-january-highlights/ Read Dr Asha Kasliwal's message from 24 Jan 2017 to FSRH members]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kasliwal, Asha}} [[Category:Women in medicine]] [[Category:People from Mumbai]] [[Category:Reproductive rights activists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Biography articles of living people]]

revision.text:
"'''Cheese-eating surrender monkeys'''", sometimes shortened to "'''surrender monkeys'''", is a pejorative term for [[French people]]. It was coined in 1995 by [[Ken Keeler]], a writer for the television series ''[[The Simpsons]]'', and has entered two Oxford quotation dictionaries.
==Origin== The term "cheese-eating surrender monkeys" first appeared in {{"-}}[['Round Springfield]]", an episode from April 1995 of the American animated television show ''[[The Simpsons]]''.<ref name="guardianYoungeHenley">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/france/story/0,,893202,00.html |accessdate=2011-08-05 |work=[[The Guardian]] |title=Wimps, weasels and monkeys — the US media view of 'perfidious France' |first1=Gary |last1=Younge |first2=Jon |last2=Henley |date=2003-02-11}}</ref> In the episode, budget cuts at [[Springfield Elementary School]] force the school's Scottish janitor, [[Groundskeeper Willie]], to teach French. Expressing his disdain for the French people, he says to his French class in his Scottish accent: "Bonjoooouuurrr, ya cheese-eatin' surrender monkeys!"{{sfn|Turner|2004|p=54}}{{sfn|Richmond & Coffman|1997|p=173}}<ref>{{cite book |title=The Simpsons In The Classroom: Embiggening the Learning Experience with the Wisdom of Springfield |page=12 |author1=Du Vernay, Denise |author2=Waltonen, Karma |publisher=McFarland |year=2010 |isbn=0-7864-4490-8}}</ref>
On the episode's [[audio commentary]], executive producer [[Al Jean]] said the line was "probably" written by ''The Simpsons'' staff writer [[Ken Keeler]].<ref name=Jean>{{cite video |people=Jean, Al |date=2005 |title=The Simpsons The Complete Sixth Season DVD commentary for the episode "[['Round Springfield]]" |medium=DVD |publisher=20th Century Fox}}</ref> In a February 2012 interview, Keeler confirmed that he coined the term; he said he considers it his best contribution to the show.<ref name=Keeler>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.ocweekly.com/heardmentality/2012/02/simpsons_talent_share_their_fa.php?page=3 |title=Best 'Simpsons' Moments: Castmembers Share Their Favorite Contributions to Celebrate the 500th Episode |work=[[OC Weekly]] |accessdate=2012-05-05 |date=2012-02-14 |author=Du Vernay, Denise |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131012025810/http://blogs.ocweekly.com/heardmentality/2012/02/simpsons_talent_share_their_fa.php?page=3# |archive-date=2013-10-12 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Al Jean commented that the staff did not expect the term to become widely used and never intended it as any kind of genuine political statement.<ref name=Jean/>
When "Round Springfield" was dubbed in French, the line became "Rendez-vous, singes mangeurs de fromage" ("Surrender, you cheese-eating monkeys").<ref name=benm>{{Cite news |last=Macintyre |first=Ben |author-link=Ben Macintyre |title=Last word: Any word that embiggens the vocabulary is cromulent with me |newspaper=[[The Times]] |date=2007-08-11 |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/books/article2234263.ece |accessdate=2011-08-03}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
==Use== Use of the term has grown outside of the United States, particularly in the United Kingdom, where ''The Simpsons'' is popular.
[[Jonah Goldberg]], an American ''[[National Review]]'' journalist, used it as the title of an April 1999 column called "Top Ten Reasons to Hate the French".<ref name=Goldberg1>{{cite news|last=Goldberg |first=Jonah |title=Cheese-Eating Surrender Monkeys From Hell |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/204434/cheese-eating-surrender-monkeys-hell/jonah-goldberg |accessdate=2011-08-05 |newspaper=[[National Review]] |date=1999-04-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150130235956/http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/204434/cheese-eating-surrender-monkeys-hell/jonah-goldberg |archivedate=January 30, 2015 }}</ref> In the run up to and during the [[Iraq War]], Goldberg reprised it to criticize European nations and France in particular for not joining the United States in its invasion and occupation of Iraq.<ref name="guardianYoungeHenley"/>
[[Ben Macintyre]] of ''[[The Times|Times of London]]'' wrote in August 2007, that it is "perhaps the most famous" of the [[List of neologisms on The Simpsons|coinages from ''The Simpsons'']] and it "has gone on to become a journalistic cliché".<ref name=benm/> The ''[[New York Post]]'' used it (as "Surrender Monkeys") as the headline for its December 7, 2006, front page, referring to the [[Iraq Study Group]], and its recommendation that American soldiers be withdrawn from [[Iraq]] by January 2008.<ref name="PBP">{{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/seven/12072006/news/nationalnews/iraq_appease_squeeze_on_w__nationalnews_.htm |title=Iraq 'Appease' Squeeze on W. |work=[[New York Post]] |date=2006-12-07 |first=Niles |last=Lathem |accessdate=2007-02-05 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070126132159/http://www.nypost.com/seven/12072006/news/nationalnews/iraq_appease_squeeze_on_w__nationalnews_.htm |archivedate=2007-01-26 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
Articles in the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' (2005 and 2009) used it to describe France's "attitude problem"<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/debate/article-1188874/HARRY-PHIBBS-Capitulation-collaboration-cheese-eating-surrender-monkeys.html |title=Capitulation, collaboration and the cheese-eating surrender monkeys |author=Phibbs, Harry |work=[[Daily Mail]] |date=2009-05-08 |accessdate=2011-08-03}}</ref> and the "muted" European reaction to the [[death of Osama bin Laden]];<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1383833/Osama-Bin-Laden-dead-US-bloggers-slam-Europeans-muted-reaction.html |title='Cheese-eating surrender monkeys': Anger grows at 'arrogant' Europeans' muted reaction to Bin Laden killing |work=[[Daily Mail]] |date=2011-05-05 |accessdate=2011-08-03}}</ref> ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' (November 2010) cited it in relation to [[Anglo-French military cooperation]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/defence/8105022/Angle-French-force-Cheese-eating-surrender-monkeys-Non.html |title=Anglo-French force: Cheese-eating surrender monkeys? Non |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |author=Rayment, Sean |date=2010-11-02 |accessdate=2011-08-03}}</ref> In August 2013, ''[[The Independent]]'' suggested an evolution away from the term, in a headline about [[French-American relations]] over the [[Syrian Civil War]].<ref>{{cite news | title = From 'cheese-eating surrender monkeys' to America's new best friends? | work = [[The Independent]] | first = John | last = Lichfield | date = 30 August 2013 | accessdate = 18 December 2013| url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/politics/from-cheeseeating-surrender-monkeys-to-americas-new-best-friends-franois-hollande-talks-tough-on-syria-after-uk-backs-down-8791471.html}}</ref>
[[Jeremy Clarkson]] used it on a 4 June 2006 episode of ''[[Top Gear (2002 TV series)|Top Gear]]'', to describe the manufacturers of the [[Citroën C6]]. He had previously used it on ''Top Gear'' in June 2003, describing the handling of the [[Renault Clio V6]]. Later on in the television show, (Series 13, Episode 5) Clarkson describes the other French drivers as "cheese-eating sideways monkeys", referring to the fact that the other drivers were overtaking him whilst sliding sideways.
[[Ned Sherrin]] selected it for inclusion in the ''Oxford Dictionary of Humorous Quotations'', being introduced in the third edition in 2005.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Oxford Dictionary of Humorous Quotations |first=Ned |last=Sherrin|authorlink=Ned Sherrin |location=Oxford; New York |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|edition=fourth |year=2008|page=xii; 137|isbn=0-19-957006-X}}</ref> It is also included in the ''Oxford Dictionary of Modern Quotations''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1561004/Simpsons-quotes-enter-new-Oxford-dictionary.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202182829/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1561004/Simpsons-quotes-enter-new-Oxford-dictionary.html|archivedate=2008-12-02|title=Simpsons quotes enter new Oxford dictionary|accessdate=2008-09-23|date=2007-08-24|author=[[Shorto, Russell]]|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] | location=London}}</ref>
Opposition Leader [[Bill Shorten]] used it in [[Australian Parliament]] on 6 March 2014, describing the [[Government of Australia]] as "the cheese-eating surrender monkeys of Australian jobs".<ref>{{cite web|author=Gabrielle Chan |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/mar/06/qantas-first-up-in-parliament-politics-live?CMP=twt_gu#block-5317be66e4b0ddf0c7eca19d |title=Qantas bill passes lower house - as it happened | Australia news |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=2016-01-30}}</ref> When asked to withdraw the comment, Shorten claimed he borrowed the line from an American politician, whom he could not name.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/latikambourke/status/441373380625698816 |title=On Twitter: "OL Bill Shorten says the cheese eating surrender monkey line is borrowed from an American politician." |publisher=Twitter.com |date=2014-03-05 |accessdate=2016-01-30|first=Latika|last=Bourke|author-link=Latika Bourke}}</ref> On 28 July 2014, Immigration Minister [[Scott Morrison]] used it to describe the [[Labor Party of Australia|Labor]] and Greens position on asylum seekers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-07-28/consular-staff-begin-processing-of-tamil-asylum-seekers/5627732 |title=Scott Morrison says 157 Tamil asylum seekers are 'economic migrants' not in danger of persecution in India, calls Labor and Greens 'surrender monkeys' |publisher=ABC News |date=28 July 2014 |accessdate=30 January 2016}}</ref>
[[Anthony Bourdain]] described fellow chef [[Patrick Clark (chef)|Patrick Clark]] in his book ''[[Kitchen Confidential (book)|Kitchen Confidential]]'' (2000) as follows: "He was kind of famous; he was big and black; most important, he was an American, one of us, not some cheese-eating, surrender specialist Froggie."{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} In the anime/manga webseries ''[[Hetalia: Axis Powers]]'', in an episode, England angrily referred to France as "You Cheese-eating surrender monkey!", only in the English dub.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}}
==See also== *[[Anti-French sentiment in the United States]] *[[Freedom fries]] *[[Axis of weasels]] *[[Francophobia]] *[[List of battles involving France]] *[[Military history of France]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ;Bibliography {{refbegin}} *{{cite book |last=Groening |first=Matt |authorlink=Matt Groening |editor1-first=Ray |editor1-last=Richmond |editor1-link=Ray Richmond |editor2-first=Antonia |editor2-last=Coffman |title=[[The Simpsons episode guides#The Simpsons: A Complete Guide to Our Favorite Family|The Simpsons: A Complete Guide to Our Favorite Family]] |edition=1st |year=1997 |location=New York |publisher=[[HarperPerennial]] |lccn=98141857 |ol=433519M |oclc=37796735 |isbn=978-0-06-095252-5 |ref={{harvid|Richmond & Coffman|1997}}}} *{{cite book |last=Turner |first=Chris |authorlink=Chris Turner (author) |title=[[Planet Simpson|Planet Simpson: How a Cartoon Masterpiece Defined a Generation]] |others=Foreword by [[Douglas Coupland]]. |edition=1st |year=2004 |location=Cambridge |publisher=[[Da Capo Press]] |oclc=670978714 |isbn=978-0-306-81341-2 |ref=harv}} {{refend}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051029101109/http://www.snpp.com/episodes/2F32.html "'Round Springfield" episode guide] – [[The Simpsons Archive]] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040609050950/http://www.snpp.com/guides/foreign.html#france References to France on ''The Simpsons''] – [[The Simpsons Archive]]
{{Ethnic slurs}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cheese-Eating Surrender Monkeys}} [[Category:Words and phrases introduced in 1995]] [[Category:American phraseology]] [[Category:Francophobia in North America]] [[Category:Pejorative terms for people]] [[Category:The Simpsons]] [[Category:Words coined in the 1990s]] [[Category:Ethnic and religious slurs]] [[Category:Metaphors referring to food and drink]] [[Category:France–United States relations]] [[Category:Metaphors referring to animals]]
