{{Infobox person | name = Lex Frieden | image = Lex Frieden 450.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = March 5, 1949 | birth_place = [[Alva, Oklahoma]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[Houston, Texas]] | alma_mater = [[University of Tulsa]]
[[University of Houston]]
[[National University of Ireland, Galway]] | occupation = Professor | networth = | spouse = | children = | website = [http://www.lexfrieden.com Lex Frieden Home] | religion = }}
'''Lex Frieden''' (born March 5, 1949){{Cite web|url=http://www.ilusa.com/WebCal/output/ilusa_calendar/wc0020120305.htm|title=3/5/2012 - Lex Frieden's Birthday|website=www.ilusa.com|access-date=2017-12-05}} is an American educator, researcher, disability policy expert and [[disability rights activist]]. Frieden has been called "a chief architect of the Americans with Disabilities Act."{{cite news|url=http://www.w5afw.com/references/AlvaNativeNowAdvocateforDisabled1992TulsaWorld.htm|work=Tulsa World |title=Alva Native Now Advocate for Disabled|author=Kim Archer |date=February 20, 1992|page= |accessdate=8 December 2012 }}{{cite news|url=http://www.w5afw.com/references/LexChron102598.htm |title= EXTRA-ORDINARY / Normal life a noble badge for paralyzed advocate for disabled |work= Houston Chronicle|date=October 25, 1998 |pages= Section A, page 1 |accessdate=5 December 2012|first= Leigh|last= Hopper }} He is also regarded as a founder and leader of the independent living movement by people with disabilities in the U.S.{{cite news|url=http://www.w5afw.com/references/harisim1.htm|title=Disabling Views on the Disabled |work= Houston Post|date=September 3, 1993|pages= Local Section, Page A29, Final Edition |accessdate=2012-12-05 |first=Paul |last=Harasim }}{{cite news |url=http://www.tmc.edu/tmcnews/11_15_98/page_01.html |title=Lex Frieden: "Champion for People with Disabilities" |author=Roger Widmeyer |work=Texas Medical Center News |date=November 15, 1998 |volume=20 |number=21 |accessdate=8 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130623072757/http://www.tmc.edu/tmcnews/11_15_98/page_01.html |archivedate=23 June 2013 |df= }} ==Biography== Lex Frieden was born in [[Alva, Oklahoma]], a rural community in northwestern Oklahoma. He graduated from Alva Senior High School in 1967 and began studying electrical engineering at [[Oklahoma State University]].{{cite book| url= | author=Edward D Berkowitz | title= Disabled policy: America's programs for the handicapped | publisher = Cambridge University Press | year = 1987 | page=196 | accessdate= }} It was as a freshman that he sustained a [[spinal cord injury]] in an automobile accident.{{cite journal | url=http://home.comcast.net/~lfrieden/FamCir04.htm | archive-url=https://archive.is/20131207225346/http://home.comcast.net/~lfrieden/FamCir04.htm | dead-url=yes | archive-date=December 7, 2013 | author=William M. Hendryx | title=Uncommon Courage | journal=[[Family Circle]] | date=January 20, 2004 | month= | accessdate= | pages=43–47 }} As part of his rehabilitation from that injury, he went to [[TIRR Memorial Hermann]] in Houston, where he met Dr. William A. Spencer, the rehabilitation medicine visionary.{{cite web |url=http://tirr.memorialhermann.org/about-tirr-memorial-hermann/history-of-tirr-memorial-hermann/ | title=Our History - TIRR Memorial Hermann | accessdate=8 December 2012 }} Dr. Spencer became Lex's mentor.{{cite book| author=Richard Verville|title=War, Politics, and Philanthropy: The History of Rehabilitation Medicine | publisher = University Press of America | year =2009 |accessdate= |page=197 }} ==Public service== Frieden's service in the 1970s included membership on a Congressional task force on science, technology and disability empaneled by [[Olin E. Teague]] (1910–1981), U.S. Congressman from Texas. The panel's mission was to study what was and was not being done in disability-related research across the entire swath of the U.S. Government. That panel's work led, in 1978, to creation of the [[National Institute on Disability and Rehabilitation Research]] (NIDRR), a unit of the [[US Department of Education]].{{cite web|url=http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015078701839;view=1up;seq=36|author=Panel on Research Programs to Aid the Handicapped, United States. Congress. House. Committee on Science and Technology|title=Report of the Panel on Research Programs to Aid the Handicapped to the Committee on Science and Technology, U.S. House of Representatives, Ninety-fifth Congress, second session|publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office | year=1978 }} [[File:DIG13636-0254.jpg|thumb|Frieden at the LBJ Presidential Library in 2014]] Frieden was one of the major figures behind the enactment of the [[Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990]]. As Executive Director of the National Council on Disability (NCD) in the mid-1980s, reporting to presidentially appointed Council members notably including Vice Chairman [[Justin Whitlock Dart, Jr.|Justin Dart, Jr.]], Frieden oversaw the work of Robert Burgdorf in writing the first drafts of what was to become the ADA. The Council issued two major reports, ''Toward Independence'' and ''On the Threshold of Independence'', to further the effort along. President George H.W. Bush signed the ADA into law on July 26, 1990.{{cite web|url=http://www.ncd.gov/publications/1997/equality_of_Opportunity_The_Making_of_the_Americans_with_Disabilities_Act|author=Jonathan M. Young|title=EQUALITY OF OPPORTUNITY:The Making of the Americans with Disabilities Act|publisher=U.S. National Council on Disability|year=1997| accessdate=6 December 2012 }} Other significant legislation inspired by the Council while Frieden was director included the Air Carrier Access Act of 1986 (ACAA) and legislation to make national parks and recreation areas accessible to people with disabilities. After leaving NCD in 1988, Frieden was appointed by Congressman Major R. Owens, Chairman of the U.S. House of Representatives Subcommittee on Select Education, to be coordinator of the newly formed, Congressional Task Force on the Rights and Empowerment of Americans with Disabilities. The role of the task force was to gather information on the extent and nature of disability discrimination in America. Justin Dart, Jr. was named chairman of the group, and working together as they had for the past five years at NCD, they produced several reports and papers which congressional committees used in the process of considering and refining the ADA prior to passage.{{cite book |url= | author= United States Congress House Committee on Education and Labor | title= Legislative history of Public Law 101-336, the Americans with Disabilities Act | publisher= U.S. Government Printing Office | page=300 | year=1990|accessdate= }} President George W. Bush appointed Frieden Chairman of the [[National Council on Disability|NCD]] and the Senate confirmed his appointment on July 26, 2002, the anniversary of the signing of the ADA. Frieden’s swearing in ceremony was conducted in the Oval Office by the President and by White House Chief of Staff [[Andrew Card]].{{cite book |url= |author= George Walker Bush, United States. Office of the Federal Register |title= Public Papers of the Presidents of the United States: George W. Bush: bk. 2. July 1 to December 31, 2002: United States. President (2001-2009 : Bush) | publisher= U.S. Government Printing Office |volume= Volume 4 of George W. Bush|year=2005|page=2234| accessdate= }} Under Frieden's leadership, the Council produced a report, ''Righting the ADA'', that made recommendations leading to enactment of the ADA Amendments Act of 2008, and they proposed a UN Convention on the Rights of People with Disabilities. Other Council priorities during Frieden's tenure as NCD chair centered on livable communities, adaptive technology and community-based services and supports for long-term care. His personal experience assisting with disaster response and recovery after Hurricanes Katrina and Rita motivated Council recommendations that resulted in passage of legislation to improve emergency preparedness and response for people with disabilities in disasters. ==Academic appointments== Frieden is Professor of Health Informatics and of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation at the [[University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston]]. He is also Professor (Adjunct) of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation at [[Baylor College of Medicine]]. Frieden directs the Independent Living Research Utilization (ILRU) program at TIRR Memorial Hermann Hospital in Houston (The Institute for Rehabilitation and Research). In 2010, the Chancellor and Vice Chancellor for the University of Texas System appointed him Chancellors Health Fellow on Disability.{{cite web | url= http://www.w5afw.com/references/NewUTHealthChancellorsFellow.htm|title=New UT Chancellor's Health Fellow to tackle disability issues |date=December 2, 2010| work=News Release: Media Relations, University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston |accessdate=8 December 2012 }} ==Education== Frieden is an Alumnus of the [[University of Tulsa]]. He was named a Distinguished Alumnus of the University in 1979, and in 2004, the Lex Frieden Presidential Scholarship was established by the University in his honor. He is also a graduate of the [[University of Houston]]. In 2004, he was awarded an honorary doctorate in law (LL.D.) by the [[National University of Ireland, Galway]].{{cite news |url=http://www.disabilityworld.org/06-08_04/news/lex.shtml |title=U.S. Disability Rights Leader Awarded Honorary Doctorate from Ireland |work=Disability World |date=June–August 2004 |number=24 |accessdate=8 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101202102922/http://www.disabilityworld.org/06-08_04/news/lex.shtml |archivedate=2 December 2010 |df= }} ==Recognition== In 1983, Frieden was recognized as one of the [[Ten Outstanding Young Americans]].[[List of Ten Outstanding Young Americans|List of Ten Outstanding Young Americans From Wikipedia]] He was the 1998 winner of the Henry B. Betts Award for outstanding achievement in disability rights.{{cite news|url=http://www.w5afw.com/references/WorkcitedChronicle.htm |title=Work for disabled cited|work= Houston Chronicle |date=October 7, 1998 |pages= Section A, Page 18|accessdate=7 December 2012 |first= |last= }} In 2011, the Texas Governor's Committee on People with Disabilities named its annual employment awards program after Frieden for his advocacy work regarding the employment of people with disabilities around the world.{{cite news|url=http://content.govdelivery.com/bulletins/gd/TXGOV-174fa8 | title=Disability History Factoid: Professor Lex Frieden|author= | date =October 26, 2011|publisher=Office of the Governor - Rick Perry|accessdate=8 December 2012 }} He also won the 2013 [[Henry Viscardi Achievement Awards]]. Frieden was awarded the prestigious Fries Prize for Human Improvement by the CDC Foundation in 2017.{{cite news|url=https://www.cdcfoundation.org/pr/2017/lex-frieden-2017-fries-prize-recipient | title=Lex Frieden Receives 2017 Fries Prize for Improving Health |author= | date =November 6, 2017 |publisher=CDC Foundation|accessdate=20 January 2018 }} ==Community service== Frieden is a member and former chairperson of the Board of [[United Spinal Association]]. He serves on the board of the Sam Houston Area Council Boy Scouts of America. In 2016, Frieden was appointed by Houston Mayor Sylvester Turner to the board of METRO, the [[Metropolitan Transit Authority of Harris County, Texas]].{{cite news|url=http://houstontx.gov/mayor/press/more-changes-at-metro.html | title= Mayor Turner Makes More Changes At METRO |author= | date =March 18, 2016 |publisher=City of Houston|accessdate=20 January 2018 }} ==Personal papers and historical archives== Frieden's extensive collection of ADA artifacts and documents is held by the US National Archives and Records Administration at the George Bush Presidential Library at College Station, Texas. The collection chronicles the disability and independent living movements by people with disabilities during the last half of the 20th century and the beginning of the 21st century..{{cite web|url=https://bush41library.tamu.edu/files/donated-collections/%5bLex%20Frieden%20Collection%5d.pdf|author=George Bush Presidential Library|title=Lex Frieden Collection, 1958-2013, bulk 1975–1991:Records on Disability Rights|publisher=U.S. National Archives and Records Administration|year=2016| accessdate=2 February 2018}} ==See also== * [[List of disability rights activists]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.lexfrieden.com Lex Frieden Homepage] *[http://www.uthouston.edu/shis/faculty-and-staff-directory/lex-frieden.htm Bio details at The University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston] *[http://www.bcm.edu/pmr/?PMID=5472 Bio details at Baylor College of Medicine] *[http://www.ilru.org Independent Living Research Utilization] *[http://www.ncd.gov National Council on Disability] {{DEFAULTSORT:Frieden, Lex}} [[Category:Disability rights activists from the United States]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Alva, Oklahoma]] [[Category:University of Tulsa alumni]] [[Category:Health informaticians]] [[Category:1949 births]]

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category 1771 in Russia‎ to [[:Category:1771 in the Russian Empire]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories_for_discussion/Log/2018_January_20]].
revision.text:
{{noref|date=July 2012}} [[File:Chumbunt.png|thumb|Plague Riot in Moscow, 1771]] '''Plague Riot''' (''Чумной бунт'' in [[Russian language|Russian]]) was a [[riot]] in [[Moscow]] in 1771 between September 15 and September 17, caused by an [[1770–1772 Russian plague|outbreak of bubonic plague]].
==History== [[File:Murder of Archbishop Ambrosius (Geoffroy, 1845).JPG|thumb|The murder of Archbishop Ambrosius. Engraving by Charles Michel Geoffroy, 1845]]The first signs of plague in Moscow appeared in late 1770, which would turn into a major [[epidemic]] in the spring of 1771. The measures undertaken by the authorities, such as creation of forced [[quarantine]]s, destruction of contaminated property without compensation or control, closing of [[public baths]], etc., caused fear and anger among the [[citizen]]s. The city's economy was mostly paralyzed because many factories, markets, stores, and administrative buildings had been closed down. All of this was followed by acute [[Economic shortage|food shortage]]s, causing deterioration of living conditions for the majority of the Muscovites. [[Dvoryane]] (Russian nobility) and well-off city dwellers left Moscow due to the plague outbreak.
The first outbursts of mass protest against the measures undertaken by the authorities took place on August 29 and September 1 in a neighborhood of [[Lefortovo District|Lefortovo]]. By early September, the rumors of an imminent uprising had already been circulating. An attempt by the [[Archbishop Ambrosius of Moscow]] to prevent the citizens from gathering at the [[Theotokos of Bogolyubovo|Icon of the Virgin Mary of Bogolyubovo]] ([[:ru:Боголюбская икона Божией Матери|Икона Боголюбской Богоматери]]) in [[Kitai-gorod]] as a quarantine measure served as an immediate cause for the Plague Riot. On September 15, huge crowds of Muscovites began to flow towards the [[Red Square]] at the sound of the alarm bell. Pushing aside a military unit, they burst into the [[Moscow Kremlin|Kremlin]] and destroyed the [[Chudov Monastery]] ([[archbishop]]'s residence) and its [[wine cellar]]s. Archbishop Ambrosius managed to escape to the [[Donskoy Monastery]].
On September 16, the riot gained in strength. Angry citizens captured the Donskoy Monastery, killed Archbishop Ambrosius, and destroyed two quarantine zones ([[Danilov Monastery]] and the one beyond the [[Serpukhov|Serpukhov Gates]]). In the afternoon, most of the rebels approached the Kremlin and were met by a number of military units. The crowd demanded the surrender of [[Lieutenant General]] [[Pyotr Yeropkin]], who had been overseeing the affairs of Moscow after [[Pyotr Saltykov]]'s departure. As soon as the Muscovites tried to attack the Kremlin's [[Spasskaya Tower|Spasskiye Gates]], the army opened fire with [[Shotgun shell|buckshot]], dispersing the crowd and capturing some of the rebels. On the morning of September 17, around 1000 people gathered at the Spasskiye gates again, demanding the release of captured rebels and elimination of quarantines. The army managed to disperse the crowd yet again and finally suppressed the riot. Some 300 people were brought to trial. A government commission headed by [[Grigory Orlov]] was sent to Moscow on September 26 to restore order. It took some measures against the plague and provided citizens with work and food, which would finally pacify the people of Moscow. The commission improved services in quarantines, put an end to the burning of property, reopened public baths, permitted trade, increased food deliveries, and organized [[public works]]. At the same time, the commission was engaged in prosecuting those who had taken part in the Plague Riot. Four of them were executed; 165 adults and twelve teenagers were subjected to punishment. With the onset of cold weather, the outbreak began to subside. Around 200,000 people died in Moscow and its outskirts during the plague.
There was another unlikely convict—the church bell that was used to start the alarm. By the order of [[Catherine the Great|Catherine II]], an executor cut the ''tang'' from the bell. For more than thirty years, the silent bell hung on the bell tower. Eventually, in 1803, it was removed and sent to the Arsenal and, in 1821, to the [[Kremlin Armoury]].
==See also== * [[The Black Plague]] * [[Copper Riot]] * [[Salt Riot]] * [[1770–1772 Russian plague]]
[[Category:Politics of the Russian Empire]] [[Category:18th century in Moscow]] [[Category:Riots and civil disorder in Russia]] [[Category:Second plague pandemic]] [[Category:1771 riots]] [[Category:1771 in the Russian Empire]] [[Category:1770 in the Russian Empire]]

{{For|myopia in humans|Myopia}}
[[File:Diceros bicornis.jpg|thumb|A [[rhinoceros]], known for its poor eyesight{{Vague|date=November 2012}}]] Some animals suffer from shortsightedness and have poor eyesight. In domestic animals, myopia, with or without [[Astigmatism (eye)|astigmatism]], occurs frequently.<ref name="DukesHewitt1935">{{cite book|last1=Dukes|first1=Henry Hugh|last2=Hewitt|first2=Earl Albon|last3=McNutt|first3=George William|title=The Physiology of Domestic Animals|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hEy4AAAAIAAJ|accessdate=31 October 2012|year=1935|publisher=Comstock publishing company, inc.}}</ref>
==In rhinoceroses == Whereas the rhinoceros may suffer from less-than-adequate eyesight, it generally survives by concentrating with its superior hearing and sense of smell.<ref name= "Kingdon 1988">{{cite book|last= Kingdon |first= Jonathan |title= East African Mammals: An Atlas of Evolution in Africa, Volume 3, Part B: Large Mammals|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xdH_Gi92-fAC&pg=PA97&dq=Myopia+in+Rhinos&hl=en&sa=X&ei=I1OTUI7ZLc3oiwKhy4D4CA&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Myopia%20in%20Rhinos&f=false|year=1988|publisher= University of Chicago Press|isbn=9780226437224|pages=96–97}}</ref> Some reports, however state that it can see better when focusing with one eye, particularly when walking, posturing, and combatting.<ref name= "Bates 1920">{{cite book|last=Bates |first= William Horatio |title= The Cure of imperfect sight by treatment without glasses|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Vl3SiyXmZVMC&pg=PA100&dq=Myopia+in+Elephants&hl=en&sa=X&ei=T1eTULeQNo_oiwK-moHwBw&sqi=2&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q&f=false|year=1920|publisher= Central Fixation Publishing Company|page=100}}</ref>
==Research == Myopia, with or without astigmatism, is the most common eye condition in horses.<ref name="DukesHewitt1935"/> Several types of occlusion myopia have been recorded in [[tree shrews]], [[macaques]], [[cat]]s and [[rat]]s, deciphered from several animal-inducing myopia models. Preliminary laboratory investigations using [[retinoscopy]] of 240 [[dog]]s<ref name=Opthol>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.iovs.org/content/33/8/2459.full.pdf|format=pdf|title=Myopia and Refractive errors in Dogs|work=Investigative Optholmology and Visual Science|volume=33| issue = 8|date=July 1992|accessdate=2 November 2012|publisher=Association for Research in Vision and Investigative Optholomology}}</ref> found myopic problems with varying degrees of refraction errors depending on the breed. In cases involving [[German Shepherd]]s, [[Rottweiler]]s and [[Miniature horse]]s, the refraction errors were indicative of myopia. [[Nuclear sclerosis]] of the [[crystalline lens]] was noticed in older dogs.<ref name=Opthol/>
Experiments into newborn [[macaque]] monkeys have revealed that surgically fusing the eyelid for one year results in eye deterioration as the eye has not had a chance to grow and develop.<ref name="ncbi">{{Cite journal | last1 = Raviola | first1 = E. | last2 = Wiesel | first2 = T. N. | doi = 10.1056/NEJM198506203122505 | title = An Animal Model of Myopia | journal = New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 312 | issue = 25 | pages = 1609–1615 | year = 1985 | pmid = 4000200 | pmc = }}</ref> Keeping monkeys in the dark for a similar period, however, does not lead to myopia.<ref name="ncbi"/> In 1996, Maurice and Mushin conducted tests on rabbits by raising their body temperatures and intraocular pressures (IOP) and noted that while younger rabbits were prone to developing myopia, older rabbits were not.<ref name="RosenfieldGilmartin1998">{{cite book|last1=Rosenfield|first1=Mark|last2=Gilmartin|first2=Bernard|title=Myopia and Nearwork|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mNT577S8uywC&pg=PA4|accessdate=31 October 2012|year=1998|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=978-0-7506-3784-8|page=4}}</ref> Some tests have revealed that myopia in some animals can be improved with eye drops containing [[zinc]], by increasing the activity of [[superoxide dismutase]] (SOD).<ref name="Schmid2004">{{cite book|last=Schmid|first=Klaus|title=Myopia Manual|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BX2r1F-GQREC&pg=PA96|accessdate=31 October 2012|date=28 June 2004|publisher=Pagefree Publishing|isbn=978-1-58961-271-6|page=96}}</ref>
The rhesus monkey's vision amplitude reduction is noticeable in its second decade of life; however the condition does not impede normal functioning. Older rhesus monkeys have more difficulty accommodating this reduction in vision amplitude, encountering difficulty in focussing on objects at close range, even objects on the ground within an arm's length.<ref name= "Rawlins1986">{{cite book|last=Rawlins|first=Richard G.|title= The Cayo Santiago Macaques: History, Behavior, and Biology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3fMCzTve890C&pg=PA244&dq=Myopia+in+Animals&hl=en&sa=X&ei=2UqTUJvwL4m8iwKD5IHgDQ&ved=0CEQQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=Myopia%20in%20Animals&f=false|year=1986|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=9780887061356|pages=243–44}}</ref>
==In zoo animals and pets== In [[Central Park Zoo]], New York, several myopic animals have been reported, including a 39-year-old [[elephant]], a [[Cape of Good Hope|Cape]] [[African buffalo|buffalo]], and some [[monkeys]].<ref name= "Bates 1920" /> Young elephants and other animals are said to be myopia free. Pet dogs with progressive myopia have been reported.<ref name="Bates 1920"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Disorders of ocular muscles, binocular movement, accommodation and refraction]] [[Category:Vision]] [[Category:Animal diseases]]

'''Nutritionism''' is a [[paradigm]] that assumes that it is the scientifically identified [[nutrients]] in foods that determine the value of individual food stuffs in the [[diet (nutrition)|diet]].<ref name="unhappy" /> In other words, it is the idea that the nutritional value of a food is the sum of all its individual nutrients, vitamins, and other components. Another aspect of the term is the implication that the only point of eating is to promote bodily health. The term is largely pejorative, implying that this way of viewing food is simplistic and harmful, and the term is usually used to label others' views. The concept's most prominent opponent, and popularizer of the term, [[journalist]] [[Michael Pollan]], argues that a food's nutritional value is "more than the sum of its parts."
Originally credited to Gyorgy Scrinis,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gyorgyscrinis.com | title = Gyorgy Scrinis' Web Page | accessdate = 2009-01-14 }}</ref> the notion was popularized by Michael Pollan.<ref name="unhappy">{{cite news | last = Pollan | first = Michael | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/28/magazine/28nutritionism.t.html | title = Unhappy Meals | publisher = [[The New York Times]] | date = 2007-01-28 }}</ref> The key to Pollan's understanding of nutritionism is "the widely shared but unexamined assumption ... that the key to understanding food is indeed the nutrient." Since nutrients are invisible, it is now necessary to rely on nutrition experts to make food choices. Because science has an incomplete understanding of how food affects the human body, Pollan argues, relying solely on information regarding individual nutrients has led people and policy makers to repeatedly make poor decisions relating to nutrition.<ref>{{cite book | last = Pollan | first = Michael | title = In Defense of Food: An Eater's Manifesto | isbn = 978-1-59420-145-5 |publisher = Penguin Press | location = New York, USA | year = 2008 }}</ref> Pollan blames nutritionism for many of the health problems relating to diet in the [[Western World]] today. He compares Nutritionism to a religion, relying on "priests" (nutritional scientists and journalists) to interpret the latest [[orthodoxy]] for the masses. Like many religions, nutritionism has divided the world into good and evil components, although what is good or evil can change dramatically with time. Pollan believes that nutritionism is inherently flawed due to a [[Reduction (philosophy)|reductive]] bias within science to isolate and study individual factors disconnected from their usual contexts such as diet and culture, factors which have repeatedly been shown to have a fundamental impact on nutritional outcomes. Even when scientists have attempted to study factors such as culture, diet, and long term consumption patterns, the enormous difficulties in making accurate measurements relating to individual nutritional components, and producing meaningful conclusions has resulted in incomplete results at best, and misleading or harmful results at worst.
[[Ben Goldacre]] wrote that nutritionism, or its attribution to scientists, is the "bollocks du jour", and that it is "driven by a set of first year undergraduate errors in interpreting scientific data."<ref>{{cite web | first = Ben | last = Goldacre | date = 2007-01-22 | publisher=New Statesman | title=Science and Fiction | pages=16–17 |accessdate=May 19, 2013 | url=http://www.newstatesman.com/sites/default/files/pdf/ethicalfood07.pdf }}</ref> In his opinion, professional researchers and medical experts bear some blame for nutritionism because they at times created unrealistic expectations about the potential benefits of their research, but that the primary promoters of nutritionism are health food manufacturers, self-proclaimed "gurus" and journalists who have an incomplete understanding of science, along with a credulous public that is willing to believe whatever simplistic theories they are told in the mass media.
At least one observer, Daniel Engber has argued that Pollan's anti-nutritionism, or anti-[[food science]] stance has taken on a dogmatic tint itself. He says, "Modern nutrition may be more of an ideology than a science, but so is Pollan's nutritional Darwinism. The two ideologies stand in direct opposition to one another, with the science-minded progressives on one side and the culinary conservatives on the other."<ref name="Enber">{{cite web | first = Daniel | last = Engber | title = Survival of the Yummiest: Should we buy Michael Pollan's nutritional Darwinism? | publisher = Slate | date = 2008-01-02 |accessdate= 2010-06-01 | url=http://www.slate.com/id/2181149/ }}</ref> One criticism is that while many scientific studies of nutrition, or the conclusions extrapolated from them by both scientists and journalists have been bad, we should not reject a scientific approach to food altogether. One reviewer notes that the study of [[vitamin]]s and nutrients led to vast improvement in treatment of diseases such as [[beriberi]] or [[scurvy]] and that with further refinement food science may well help combat other diseases and health conditions. The complexity of food science should not be taken as a reason to abandon systematic investigation of it. Daniel Engber also argues that Pollan over idealizes the diet of our ancestors, and believes that it may not be well suited to our modern needs.<ref name="Enber"/>
== See also == * [[List of diets]]
==References== * {{cite book|last1=Scrinis|first1=Gyorgy|title=Nutritionism: The Science and Politics of Dietary Advice|date=2013|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=9780231527149|url=http://cup.columbia.edu/book/nutritionism/9780231156561|accessdate=15 April 2015}} <references/>
[[Category:Nutrition]]

Alter: journal, last. Add: year, url, pmid. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[User:Headbomb|Headbomb]]
revision.text:
The '''obesity paradox''' is a medical [[hypothesis]] which holds that [[obesity]] (and [[hypercholesterolemia|high cholesterol]], when the more global term reverse epidemiology is used) may, [[counterintuitive]]ly, be protective and associated with greater survival in certain groups of people, such as very elderly individuals or those with certain [[chronic disease]]s. It further postulates that normal to low [[body mass index]] or normal values of [[cholesterol]] may be detrimental and associated with higher [[Mortality rate|mortality]] in asymptomatic people.
== Description == The terminology reverse epidemiology was first proposed by [[Kamyar Kalantar-Zadeh]] in the journal ''[[Kidney International]]'' in 2003<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1046/j.1523-1755.2003.00803.x |title=Reverse epidemiology of cardiovascular risk factors in maintenance dialysis patients |year=2003 |last1=Kalantar-Zadeh |first1=Kamyar |last2=Block |first2=Gladys |last3=Humphreys |first3=Michael H. |last4=Kopple |first4=Joel D. |journal=Kidney International |volume=63 |issue=3 |pages=793–808 |pmid=12631061}}</ref> and in the ''[[Journal of the American College of Cardiology]]'' in 2004.<ref name="Kalantar-Zadeh2">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.jacc.2003.11.039 |title=Reverse epidemiology of conventional cardiovascular risk factors in patients with chronic heart failure |year=2004 |last1=Kalantar-Zadeh |first1=Kamyar |last2=Block |first2=Gladys |last3=Horwich |first3=Tamara |last4=Fonarow |first4=Gregg C |journal=Journal of the American College of Cardiology |volume=43 |issue=8 |pages=1439–44 |pmid=15093881}}</ref> It is a contradiction to prevailing concepts of prevention of [[atherosclerosis]] and [[cardiovascular disease]]; however, active [[prophylaxis|prophylactic treatment]] of heart disease in otherwise healthy, asymptomatic people is and has been controversial in the medical community for several years.<ref name="Naghavi">{{cite journal |doi=10.1097/01.hpc.0000249784.29151.54 |title=The First SHAPE (Screening for Heart Attack Prevention and Education) Guideline |year=2006 |last1=Naghavi |first1=Morteza |last2=Falk |first2=Erling |last3=Hecht |first3=Harvey S. |last4=Shah |first4=Prediman K. |journal=Critical Pathways in Cardiology |volume=5 |issue=4 |pages=187–90 |pmid=18340236 |author5=Shape Task Force}}</ref><ref name="Pearson">{{cite journal |doi=10.1377/hlthaff.26.1.49 |title=The Prevention of Cardiovascular Disease: Have We Really Made Progress? |year=2007 |last1=Pearson |first1=T. A. |journal=Health Affairs |volume=26 |pages=49–60 |pmid=17211013 |issue=1}}</ref>
The mechanism responsible for this reversed association is unknown, but it has been suggested that, in [[chronic kidney disease]] patients, "The common occurrence of persistent inflammation and protein energy wasting in advanced CKD [chronic kidney disease] seems to a large extent to account for this paradoxical association between traditional risk factors and CV outcomes in this patient population."<ref>[http://www.njmonline.nl/article.php?i=122&d=551&a=873 Vascular disease and chronic renal failure: new insights]</ref> Other research has proposed that the paradox may be explained by [[adipose tissue]] storing lipophilic chemicals that would otherwise be toxic to the body.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hong|first1=N-S|last2=Kim|first2=K-S|last3=Lee|first3=I-K|last4=Lind|first4=P M|last5=Lind|first5=L|last6=Jacobs|first6=D R|last7=Lee|first7=D-H|title=The association between obesity and mortality in the elderly differs by serum concentrations of persistent organic pollutants: a possible explanation for the obesity paradox|journal=International Journal of Obesity|date=27 September 2011|volume=36|issue=9|pages=1170–1175|doi=10.1038/ijo.2011.187|pmid=21946706}}</ref>
The obesity paradox (excluding cholesterol paradox) was first described in 1999 in overweight and obese people undergoing hemodialysis,<ref name=Schmidt2007>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1525-139X.2007.00349.x |title=CARDIOVASCULAR AND SURVIVAL PARADOXES IN DIALYSIS PATIENTS: Obesity-Survival Paradox-Still a Controversy? |year=2007 |last1=Schmidt |first1=Darren S. |last2=Salahudeen |first2=Abdulla K. |journal=Seminars in Dialysis |volume=20 |issue=6 |pages=486–92 |pmid=17991192}}</ref> and has subsequently been found in those with [[heart failure]],<ref name="Kalantar-Zadeh2"/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sharma|first1=A|last2=Lavie|first2=CJ|last3=Borer|first3=JS|last4=Vallakati|first4=A|last5=Goel|first5=S|last6=Lopez-Jimenez|first6=F|last7=Arbab-Zadeh|first7=A|last8=Mukherjee|first8=D|last9=Lazar|first9=JM|title=Meta-analysis of the relation of body mass index to all-cause and cardiovascular mortality and hospitalization in patients with chronic heart failure.|journal=The American Journal of Cardiology|date=15 May 2015|volume=115|issue=10|pages=1428–34|doi=10.1016/j.amjcard.2015.02.024|pmid=25772740|url=http://espace.library.uq.edu.au/view/UQ:355802/UQ355802_OA.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Padwal|first1=R|last2=McAlister|first2=F A|last3=McMurray|first3=J J V|last4=Cowie|first4=M R|last5=Rich|first5=M|last6=Pocock|first6=S|last7=Swedberg|first7=K|last8=Maggioni|first8=A|last9=Gamble|first9=G|last10=Ariti|first10=C|last11=Earle|first11=N|last12=Whalley|first12=G|last13=Poppe|first13=K K|last14=Doughty|first14=R N|last15=Bayes-Genis|first15=A|title=The obesity paradox in heart failure patients with preserved versus reduced ejection fraction: a meta-analysis of individual patient data|journal=International Journal of Obesity|date=31 October 2013|volume=38|issue=8|pages=1110–1114|doi=10.1038/ijo.2013.203|pmid=24173404}}</ref> [[myocardial infarction]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wang|first1=L|last2=Liu|first2=W|last3=He|first3=X|last4=Chen|first4=Y|last5=Lu|first5=J|last6=Liu|first6=K|last7=Cao|first7=K|last8=Yin|first8=P|title=Association of overweight and obesity with patient mortality after acute myocardial infarction: A meta-analysis of prospective studies|journal=International Journal of Obesity (2005)|date=4 September 2015|doi=10.1038/ijo.2015.176|pmid=26338077|volume=40|issue=2|pages=220–8}}</ref> [[acute coronary syndrome]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Niedziela|first1=J|last2=Hudzik|first2=B|last3=Niedziela|first3=N|last4=Gąsior|first4=M|last5=Gierlotka|first5=M|last6=Wasilewski|first6=J|last7=Myrda|first7=K|last8=Lekston|first8=A|last9=Poloński|first9=L|last10=Rozentryt|first10=P|title=The obesity paradox in acute coronary syndrome: a meta-analysis.|journal=European Journal of Epidemiology|date=November 2014|volume=29|issue=11|pages=801–12|doi=10.1007/s10654-014-9961-9|pmid=25354991|pmc=4220102}}</ref> older [[nursing home]] residents,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Veronese|first1=N|last2=Cereda|first2=E|last3=Solmi|first3=M|last4=Fowler|first4=SA|last5=Manzato|first5=E|last6=Maggi|first6=S|last7=Manu|first7=P|last8=Abe|first8=E|last9=Hayashi|first9=K|last10=Allard|first10=JP|last11=Arendt|first11=BM|last12=Beck|first12=A|last13=Chan|first13=M|last14=Audrey|first14=YJ|last15=Lin|first15=WY|last16=Hsu|first16=HS|last17=Lin|first17=CC|last18=Diekmann|first18=R|last19=Kimyagarov|first19=S|last20=Miller|first20=M|last21=Cameron|first21=ID|last22=Pitkälä|first22=KH|last23=Lee|first23=J|last24=Woo|first24=J|last25=Nakamura|first25=K|last26=Smiley|first26=D|last27=Umpierrez|first27=G|last28=Rondanelli|first28=M|last29=Sund-Levander|first29=M|last30=Valentini|first30=L|last31=Schindler|first31=K|last32=Törmä|first32=J|last33=Volpato|first33=S|last34=Zuliani|first34=G|last35=Wong|first35=M|last36=Lok|first36=K|last37=Kane|first37=JM|last38=Sergi|first38=G|last39=Correll|first39=CU|title=Inverse relationship between body mass index and mortality in older nursing home residents: a meta-analysis of 19,538 elderly subjects.|journal=Obesity Reviews|date=November 2015|volume=16|issue=11|pages=1001–15|doi=10.1111/obr.12309|pmid=26252230|url=http://urn.kb.se/resolve?urn=urn:nbn:se:liu:diva-121461}}</ref> and [[chronic obstructive pulmonary disease]] (COPD).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cao|first1=Chao|last2=Wang|first2=Ran|last3=Wang|first3=Jianmiao|last4=Bunjhoo|first4=Hansvin|last5=Xu|first5=Yongjian|last6=Xiong|first6=Weining|last7=Simpson|first7=Colin|title=Body Mass Index and Mortality in Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease: A Meta-Analysis|journal=PLoS ONE|date=24 August 2012|volume=7|issue=8|pages=e43892|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0043892|pmid=22937118|pmc=3427325}}</ref>
In people with [[heart failure]], those with a [[body mass index]] between 30.0–34.9 had lower mortality than those with what would normally be considered an ideal weight. This has been attributed to the fact that people often lose weight as they become progressively more ill.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.amjcard.2006.04.039 |title=The Obesity Paradox: Fact or Fiction? |year=2006 |last1=Habbu |first1=Amit |last2=Lakkis |first2=Nasser M. |last3=Dokainish |first3=Hisham |journal=The American Journal of Cardiology |volume=98 |issue=7 |pages=944–8 |pmid=16996880}}</ref> Similar findings have been made in other types of heart disease. People with class I obesity and heart disease do not have greater rates of further heart problems than people of normal weight who also have heart disease. In people with greater degrees of obesity, however, risk of further events is increased.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(06)69251-9 |title=Association of bodyweight with total mortality and with cardiovascular events in coronary artery disease: A systematic review of cohort studies |year=2006 |last1=Romero-Corral |first1=Abel |last2=Montori |first2=Victor M |last3=Somers |first3=Virend K |last4=Korinek |first4=Josef |last5=Thomas |first5=Randal J |last6=Allison |first6=Thomas G |last7=Mookadam |first7=Farouk |last8=Lopez-Jimenez |first8=Francisco |journal=The Lancet |volume=368 |issue=9536 |pmid=16920472 |pages=666–78}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.ahj.2008.02.014 |title=Body mass index and mortality in heart failure: A meta-analysis |year=2008 |last1=Oreopoulos |first1=Antigone |last2=Padwal |first2=Raj |last3=Kalantar-Zadeh |first3=Kamyar |last4=Fonarow |first4=Gregg C. |last5=Norris |first5=Colleen M. |last6=McAlister |first6=Finlay A. |journal=American Heart Journal |volume=156 |pages=13–22 |pmid=18585492 |issue=1}}</ref> Even after [[Coronary artery bypass surgery|cardiac bypass surgery]], no increase in mortality is seen in the overweight and obese.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/oby.2007.36 |title=Effect of Obesity on Short- and Long-term Mortality Postcoronary Revascularization: A Meta-analysis |year=2008 |last1=Oreopoulos |first1=Antigone |last2=Padwal |first2=Raj |last3=Norris |first3=Colleen M |last4=Mullen |first4=John C |last5=Pretorius |first5=Victor |last6=Kalantar-Zadeh |first6=Kamyar |journal=Obesity |volume=16 |issue=2 |pages=442–50 |pmid=18239657}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mariscalco|first1=G|last2=Wozniak|first2=MJ|last3=Dawson|first3=AG|last4=Serraino|first4=GF|last5=Porter|first5=R|last6=Nath|first6=M|last7=Klersy|first7=C|last8=Kumar|first8=T|last9=Murphy|first9=GJ|title=Body Mass Index and Mortality Among Adults Undergoing Cardiac Surgery: A Nationwide Study With a Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis.|journal=Circulation|date=28 February 2017|volume=135|issue=9|pages=850–863|doi=10.1161/CIRCULATIONAHA.116.022840|pmid=28034901}}</ref> One study found that the improved survival could be explained by the more aggressive treatment obese people receive after a cardiac event.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.ahj.2005.09.024 |title=The obesity paradox in non–ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndromes: Results from the Can Rapid risk stratification of Unstable angina patients Suppress ADverse outcomes with Early implementation of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Guidelines Quality Improvement Initiative |year=2006 |last1=Diercks |first1=Deborah B. |last2=Roe |first2=Matthew T. |last3=Mulgund |first3=Jyotsna |last4=Pollack |first4=Charles V. |last5=Kirk |first5=J. Douglas |last6=Gibler |first6=W. Brian |last7=Ohman |first7=E. Magnus |last8=Smith |first8=Sidney C. |last9=Boden |first9=William E. |last10=Peterson |first10=Eric D. |journal=American Heart Journal |volume=152 |pages=140–8 |pmid=16824844 |issue=1|display-authors=8 }}</ref> Another found that if one takes into account COPD in those with [[peripheral artery disease]], the benefit of obesity no longer exists.<ref>[http://www.ima.org.il/FilesUpload/IMAJ/0/40/20270.pdf "Obesity Paradox" in Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease]</ref>
== Criticisms ==
The obesity paradox has been criticized on the grounds of being an artifact arising from biases in observational studies. Strong confounding by smoking has been noted by several researchers.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/oby.21239 |title=Smoking and reverse causation create an obesity paradox in cardiovascular disease. |year=2015 |last1=Stokes |first1=Andrew |journal=Obesity |volume=23 |issue=12 |pages=2485–90 |pmid=26421898 |pmc=4701612}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1097/EDE.0000000000000075 |pmid=24608666 |title=Obesity Paradox: Conditioning on Disease Enhances Biases in Estimating the Mortality Risks of Obesity. |year=2014 |last1=Preston |first1=Samuel |last2=Stokes |first2=Andrew |journal=Epidemiology |volume=25 |issue=3 |pages=454–461|pmc=3984024 }}</ref> Since smokers, who are subject to higher mortality rates, also tend to be leaner, inadequate adjustment for smoking would lead to underestimations of the risk ratios associated with the overweight and obese categories of BMI. In an analysis of 1.46 million individuals, restriction to never-smoking participants greatly reduced the mortality estimates in the underweight group, as well as strengthening the estimates in the overweight and obese groups.<ref name="NEJM1">{{cite journal |authors=Berrington de Gonzalez A, Hartge P, Cerhan JR, Flint AJ, Hannan L, MacInnis RJ, Moore SC, Tobias GS, Anton-Culver H, Freeman LB, Beeson WL, Clipp SL, English DR, Folsom AR, Freedman DM, Giles G, Hakansson N, Henderson KD, Hoffman-Bolton J, Hoppin JA, Koenig KL, Lee IM, Linet MS, Park Y, Pocobelli G, Schatzkin A, Sesso HD, Weiderpass E, Willcox BJ, Wolk A, Zeleniuch-Jacquotte A, Willett WC, Thun MJ |title=Body-mass index and mortality among 1.46 million white adults |journal=The New England Journal of Medicine |volume=363 |issue=23 |pages=2211–9 |year=2010 |pmid=21121834 |pmc=3066051 |doi=10.1056/NEJMoa1000367}}</ref> A similar 2016 study found that a low BMI that has been "induced by healthy lifestyles" is the best method of reducing the risk of premature death.<ref>Veronese, Nicola; Li, Yanping; Manson, JoAnn E; Willett, Walter C; Fontana, Luigi; Hu, Frank B. (20106) "Combined associations of body weight and lifestyle factors with all cause and cause specific mortality in men and women: prospective cohort study", ''BMJ'', v355. [[Digital object identifier|doi]]: [https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.i5855 https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.i5855].</ref>
Another concern is reverse causation due to illness-induced weight loss. That is, it may not be low BMI that is causing death (and thereby making obesity seem protective) but rather imminent death causing low BMI. Indeed, unintentional weight loss is an extremely significant predictor of mortality.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1017/S0954422409990035 |title=A review and meta-analysis of the effect of weight loss on all-cause mortality risk. |year=2009 |last1=Harrington |first1=Mary |last2=Gibson |first2=Sigrid |last3=Cottrell |first3=Richard |journal=Nutr Res Rev |volume=22 |issue=1 |pages=93–108 |pmid=19555520}}</ref> Sick individuals often undergo weight loss before death, and classifying those individuals as lean greatly inflates the mortality rate in the normal and underweight categories of BMI, while lowering the risk in the higher BMI categories. Studies that employ strategies to reduce reverse causation such as excluding sick individuals at baseline and introducing time lag to exclude deaths at the beginning of follow-up<ref name="Lancet1">{{cite journal |author=Prospective Studies Collaboration |title=Body-mass index and cause-specific mortality in 900 000 adults: collaborative analyses of 57 prospective studies |journal=The Lancet |volume=373 |issue=9669 |pages=1083–1096 |year=2009 |pmid=19299006 |pmc=2662372 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(09)60318-4}}</ref> have yielded estimates of increased risk for body mass indices above 25 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Critics of the "paradox" have also argued that studies supporting its existence almost always use BMI as the only measure of obesity. However, because BMI is an imperfect method of measuring obesity, critics argue that studies using other measures of obesity in addition to BMI, such as [[waist circumference]] and [[waist to hip ratio]], render the existence of the "paradox" questionable.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Chrysant|first1=Steven G.|last2=Chrysant|first2=George S.|title=New insights into the true nature of the obesity paradox and the lower cardiovascular risk|journal=Journal of the American Society of Hypertension|date=January 2013|volume=7|issue=1|pages=85–94|doi=10.1016/j.jash.2012.11.008|pmid=23321407}}</ref>
One probable methodological explanation for the obesity paradox is [[Collider (epidemiology)|collider]] stratification bias, which commonly emerges when one restricts or stratifies on a factor (the 'collider') that is caused by both the exposure (or its descendents) and the outcome (or its ancestors/risk factors).<ref>{{Cite book|title=Modern epidemiology|last=J.|first=Rothman, Kenneth|others=Greenland, Sander, 1951-, Lash, Timothy L.|isbn=9780781755641|edition=3rd edition, thoroughly revised and updated|location=Philadelphia|oclc=169455558|year = 2008}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Banack|first=Hailey R.|last2=Kaufman|first2=Jay S.|date=May 2014|title=The obesity paradox: Understanding the effect of obesity on mortality among individuals with cardiovascular disease|url=https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0091743514000681|journal=Preventive Medicine|volume=62|pages=96–102|doi=10.1016/j.ypmed.2014.02.003|pmid=24525165|issn=0091-7435}}</ref> To put it in the context of the obesity paradox, the exposure is the obesity measurement (e.g., BMI), the outcome is mortality, and the collider is one of certain chronic diseases ( take CVD as an example). First let's assume that obesity does not cause post-CVD death (i.e., no effect) and see how the bias arises. Among CVD patients, those with low BMI must have some other risk factors (e.g., smoking) to make CVD occurred; whereas those without major risk factors other than obesity (e.g., smoking) are more likely to have higher BMI since it's the only left known major risk factors for CVD. Let's further assume that these other major risk factors for CVD are also risk factors for post-CVD death (which is more often the case). We would come to the finding that those with lower BMI (normal weight group) but developed CVD are more likely to die because they tend to have other risk factors for both CVD and death, and those CVD cases with higher BMI (obesity group) are less likely to die due to a relative lack of these risk factors. Thus restricting to CVD patients yields a 'protective effect' of obesity against post-CVD death even if there is no effect to begin with. The spurious protective effect of obesity can be huge enough to reverse a detrimental effect when the selection proportion (CVD cases among the source population) becomes small.<ref name=":0" />
==See also== * [[French paradox]] * [[Mediterranean diet]] * [[Israeli paradox]] * [[Diet food]] * [[Negative-calorie food]] * [[Olestra]] *[[Online weight loss plans]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite journal |doi=10.1001/jama.2012.9282 |pmid=22871870 |laysummary=http://diabetes.webmd.com/news/20120807/obesity-paradox-thin-not-in-for-type-2-diabetes |laysource=[[WebMD]] |laydate=August 7, 2012 |title=Association of Weight Status With Mortality in Adults With Incident Diabetes |year=2012 |journal=JAMA |volume=000 |issue=8 |pages=9000–9001|first1=Mercedes R. |last1=Carnethon |first2=Peter John D. |last2=De Chavez |first3=Mary L. |last3=Biggs |first4=Cora E. |last4=Lewis |first5=James S. |last5=Pankow |first6=Alain G. |last6=Bertoni |first7=Sherita H. |last7=Golden |first8=Kiang |last8=Liu |first9=Kenneth J. |last10=Campbell-Jenkins |first10=Brenda |last11=Dyer |first11=Alan R. |last9=Mukamal|display-authors=8 |pmc=3467944 }} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1001/jama.2012.9776 |pmid=22871873 |title=Beyond the Obesity Paradox in Diabetes: Fitness, Fatness, and Mortality |year=2012 |journal=JAMA |volume=308 |issue=6 |pages=619–620|first1=Hermes |last1=Florez |first2=Sumaya |last2=Castillo-Florez}}

revision.text:
{{redirect|Drugstore}} [[File:Pharmacy, Gangtok, India (8083933798).jpg|thumb|right|In [[:en:Gangtok|Gangtok]], India, this pharmacy has a counter open to the street for walk-up business.]]
A '''pharmacy''' (also called "'''drugstore'''" in [[American English]] or "'''community pharmacy'''" or "'''chemist's'''" in [[Commonwealth English]]) is a [[retail]] shop which provides [[prescription drugs]], among other products. At the pharmacy, a [[pharmacist]] oversees the fulfillment of [[medical prescriptions]] and is available to give advice on their offerings of [[over-the-counter drugs]]. A typical pharmacy would be in the [[commercial area]] of a community.
==Characteristics of a good pharmacy== The [[American Association of Colleges of Pharmacy]] recommends that consumers choose a pharmacy at which they can have a consulting relationship with the pharmacist.<ref name="Consumer Reports 2016">{{cite web|title=Pharmacy Buying Guide|url=http://www.consumerreports.org/cro/pharmacies/buying-guide.htm|website=Consumer Reports|accessdate=13 February 2017|date=May 2016}}</ref> Anyone using drugs benefits when they have easier access to a pharmacist Being timely includes both processing the request quickly and having drug stock available to fill the prescription.<ref name="Consumer Reports 2016"/> Some consumers need drugs delivered to their home, perhaps by mail, and may select a pharmacy which offers that service.<ref name="Consumer Reports 2016"/> Different pharmacies may charge different prices for the same drugs, so shopping for lower prices may identify a pharmacy offering better value.<ref name="Consumer Reports 2016"/> In addition to fulfilling prescriptions, a pharmacy might offer [[preventive healthcare]] services like vaccinations.<ref name="Consumer Reports 2016"/> Up-to-date technology at a pharmacy can assist a patient with prescription reminders and alerts about potential negative drug interactions, thereby reducing [[medical errors]].<ref name="Consumer Reports 2016"/>
== Duties == The [[International Pharmaceutical Federation]] has declared their vision of a community-based pharmacist:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fip.org/community_pharmacy |title=Community Pharmacy Section |publisher=International Pharmaceutical Federation (FIP) |accessdate=8 July 2014}}</ref>
* An expert in [[pharmaceutical care]], [[pharmacotherapy]] and [[health promotion]] * A professional communicator with [[patient]]s, other [[healthcare provider]]s and decision makers * Deliver high quality products, services and [[communication]] * Document their work and communicate the outcome to professional colleagues.
==Responsibilities ==
Community-based pharmacists' responsibilities include: checking and dispensing of [[prescription drugs]], providing advice on [[drug]] selection and usage to doctors and other health professionals and counseling patients in health promotion, [[disease prevention]] and the proper use of medicines.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.psa.org.au/about/pharmacy-as-a-career/what-pharmacists-do-and-where-they-work |title=What pharmacists do and where they work |publisher=Pharmaceutical Society of Australia |accessdate=8 July 2014}}</ref>
In most countries regulations govern how dispensaries may operate, with specific requirements for storage conditions, equipment and record keeping.
==Clinical roles==
It is becoming more common for pharmacists to take on extended roles that provide more clinical care directly to patients as part of a primary care team. There are around 11,400 community pharmacies in England. Many are open for extended hours in the evenings and weekends and they are accessible without appointment.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scotland.gov.uk/Topics/Health/NHS-Workforce/Pharmacists/Pharmacy |title=Pharmacy |publisher=[[Scottish Government]] |accessdate=8 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rpharms.com/pharmacy-roles/community-pharmacy.asp |title=Careers in pharmacy: Pharmacy roles: Community pharmacy |publisher=[[Royal Pharmaceutical Society]] (RPS) |accessdate=8 July 2014}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== In the English [[National Health Service (England)|NHS]] there are 438 million visits nationally to community pharmacies a year for health related reasons. More than 1 billion prescription items were dispensed in 2012. More than £14 billion is spent on prescribed drugs annually.<ref>{{cite news|title=How the health system is skewed towards harm for pill-popping pensioners|url=http://www.econotimes.com/How-the-health-system-is-skewed-towards-harm-for-pill-popping-pensioners-121671|accessdate=30 November 2015|publisher=EconoTimes|date=27 November 2015}}</ref> Under the 2005 NHS Community Pharmacy contract all community pharmacists in England and Wales provide:<ref>{{cite web|title=About community pharmacy|url=http://psnc.org.uk/psncs-work/about-community-pharmacy/|website=Pharmaceutical Services Negotiating Committee|accessdate=30 November 2015}}</ref> *Dispensing Service *Repeat Dispensing Service: This allows the patient to collect regular repeat prescription medicines for an agreed period of time, without having to go back to their GP *Disposal of Unwanted Medicines. *Promotion of Healthy Lifestyles. *Signposting to other Services. *Support for Self-Care: advice on treating minor illnesses and long term conditions.
Widely available Advanced Services:
*Medicines Use Review & Prescription Intervention. *New Medicine Service. For patients who have been given their first prescription for a medicine to treat Asthma and COPD, Type 2 diabetes, Hypertension or Anticoagulant Therapy. *Appliance Use Review Service. *Flu Vaccination.
Enhanced Services which are not available unless locally commissioned: *Minimising Adverse Effects and Admissions Related to Medicines. *Discharge and Transfer Planning. *Managing Dental Pain.
== Support staff ==
To help pharmacists be able to take on extended roles, it is common for them to work as part of a team that can include pharmacy technicians, dispensing assistants and counter assistants.<ref name="PSNCabout">{{cite web |url=http://psnc.org.uk/psncs-work/about-community-pharmacy/ |title=About Community Pharmacy |publisher=Pharmaceutical Services Negotiating Committee |accessdate=8 July 2014}}</ref>
==Ownership==
In parts of mainland Europe, the pharmacist is required to own the pharmacy of which she or he is the licensee. Under this arrangement, a pharmacist can be the operator of only a single outlet.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.epheu.eu/pharmacy-in-europe/france/ |title=Pharmacy in Europe: France |publisher=Employed community Pharmacists in Europe (EPhEU) |accessdate=8 July 2014}}</ref> In the UK, 60% of all community pharmacies are owned by companies that own multiple pharmacies.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.epheu.eu/news/uk/ |title=News from UK |publisher=Employed community Pharmacists in Europe (EPhEU) |accessdate=8 July 2014}}</ref>
In the United States, more than 25% of independent owners have ownership in two or more pharmacies.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ncpanet.org/home/independent-pharmacy-today |title=Independent Pharmacy Today |publisher=National Community Pharmacists Association |accessdate=8 July 2014}}</ref>
Most of New Zealand's community pharmacies are owner-operated.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.pjonline.com/tomorrows-pharmacist/practice_overseas/new_zealand |title=Sun, surf, snow and pharmacy- pharmacy practice in New Zealand |work=PJ online |last=Gauld |first=Natalie |date=8 December 2010 |accessdate=8 July 2014}}</ref> In Australia, pharmacists recognise the need to integrate professional pharmacy services into the health system to meet the changing health care needs of the population.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.psa.org.au/policies/community-pharmacy-agreement-principless |title=Principles for Community Pharmacy Agreements |publisher=Pharmaceutical Society of Australia |accessdate=8 July 2014}}</ref>
==Society and culture== A survey conducted by PrescribeWellness found that almost half of Americans older than 40 years-old value pharmacies that offer [[preventative care]] services, and would be willing to transfer their [[Prescription drug|prescriptions]] to pharmacies that offer those services.<ref name="Vecchione DrugTopics">{{cite journal|last1=Vecchione|first1=Anthony|title=Patients Prefer Pharmacies That Offer Preventive Care|journal=DrugTopics|date=February 2018|volume=162|issue=2|page=6}}</ref> Patients also value pharmacies where they can receive medical advice concerning their prescription medications, how those medications may [[drug interaction|interact]] with each other, and receive [[over-the-counter drug]] recommendations for the management of common ailments.<ref name="Vecchione DrugTopics" /> In a survey of over 1,000 U.S. adults older than 40 years-old conducted by Propeller Insights, 67% of patients responded that they would prefer that their pharmacist discuss new prescriptions with them, rather than their [[physician]], because they viewed their pharmacist as "better at explaining [[side effects]] and has more time to spend with them."<ref name="Vecchione DrugTopics" />
==Gallery== <gallery class="center" caption="" widths="220px" heights="160px"> File:Szczecin al Jana Pawla II 42 zabytek.jpg|Contemporary pharmacy in an older building File:Walgreens store.jpg|A [[chain store]] pharmacy in the United States File:Vitusapotek 2012.JPG|A pharmacy in Norway that is part of a shopping mall File:Ethio 12.jpg|Interior of a pharmacy in Ethiopia </gallery>
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == *[http://www.fip.org International Pharmaceutical Federation (FIP)] *[https://trungtamthuoc.com/ Pharmacy Vietnam]
[[Category:Pharmacy]] [[Category:Shops]]

revision.comment: +[[Category:Health charities in the United States]]; +[[Category:Foreign charities operating in Russia]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
'''Russian Medical Fund''' was a humanitarian organization founded in Vienna, Virginia,<ref>Schanke, Jerry, "Giving the Gift of Life," Vienna Times, 16 August 2001, pp. A1, A7</ref> to support medical care for children in [[Saint Petersburg]], Russia during the post-Soviet period.<ref>PetersburgCity News, 20 June 2001, "A new heart surgery room opened in Children's City Hospital No. 1" City section, front page</ref><ref>GuideStar USA website, "Russian Medical Fund" organization # 54-1869946</ref>
Russian Medical Fund provided supplies, equipment, and physician training<ref>Civil Society International, website, "International Organizations: Health and Medicine"</ref> to the pediatric cardiac unit of Children's Hospital #1<ref>Children's Hospital No. 1, St. Petersburg, Cardiac Surgery Department website</ref><ref>GuideStar, "Russian Medical Fund"</ref> of Saint Petersburg, Russia. The fund provided for a new 7-bed pediatric intensive care unit,<ref>PetersburgCity News, City section, front page</ref> purchased a heart-lung machine,<ref> King, Sheri, "To Russia, with Love," The Middletown Journal, 22 September 2001, local news, p. B5</ref> and underwrote a complete renovation of the congenital surgery operating suite.<ref>Harvard Business School Alumni Bulletin, 1 October 2002, p. 49</ref> In addition, RMF advocated the continuation of U.S. funding for civil society programs there<ref>Johnson's Russia List, website, 20 February 2006, letter to the editor, "Less Money for Democracy"</ref> and co-sponsored humanitarian and medical work being done by a related organization, Global Healing.<ref>Global Healing, website, "Contributors"</ref>
The organization was created as a [[private foundation]] in 1996<ref>GuideStar, "Russian Medical Fund"</ref> and continued operations until 2008.<ref>Firedoglake, website, 24 November 2008, "Russian Medical Fund"</ref> The fund was affiliated with the American International Health Alliance.<ref>American International Health Alliance, website, "All AIHA Strategic Partners"</ref>
== Notes == {{Reflist}}
==See also== * [[Healthcare in Russia]]
== References == * American International Health Alliance, website, "All AIHA Strategic Partners". * Cardiac Surgery Department, Children's Hospital Number 1, St. Petersburg, Russia, website. * Civil Society International, website, "International Organizations: Health and Medicine". * Firedoglake, website, 24 November 2008, "Russian Medical Fund". * Global Healing, Berkeley, California, website, "Contributors". * GuideStar USA, Partner Report on Russian Medical Fund, EIN number 54-1869946. * Harvard Business School Alumni Bulletin, 1 October 2002, p. 49. * Johnson's Russia List, website, 20 February 2006, #27 - JRL 2006-43 - JRL Home. * King, Sheri, "To Russia, with Love," The Middletown Journal, Middletown, Ohio, 22 September 2001, local news, p. B5. * PetersburgCity News, St. Petersburg, Russia, 20 June 2001, City news section, "A new heart surgery room opened in Children's City Hospital No. 1". * Schanke, Jerry, "Giving the Gift of Life," Vienna Times, Vienna, Virginia, 16 August 2001, pp. A1, A7.
==External links== * [http://www.aiha.com/en/WhoWeAre/StrategicPartners_All.asp American International Health Alliance] * [http://www.dgb.spb.ru/napr_rab/cardio/cardio.htm Cardiac Surgery, Children's Hospital website] * [http://www.civilsocietyinternational.org/usnisorg/usnishlt.htm Civil Society International] * [http://my.firedoglake.com/egregious/2008/11/24/russian-medical-fund-24-november-2008 Firedoglake] * [http://www.globalhealing.org/contributors Global Healing] * [http://www.guidestar.org/PartnerReport.aspx?ein=54-1869946&Partner=Amex Guidestar partner report] * [https://www.alumni.hbs.edu/stories/Pages/story-bulletin.aspx?num=2138 Harvard Business School Alumni Bulletin] * [http://www.russialist.org/2006-46-27.php Johnson's Russia List] * [http://petersburgcity.com/news/city/2001/06/20/news374 PetersburgCity News article]
